description: The Planning, Protection and Optimization (PPO) module focuses on the practical application of PPO practices to enable capacity, availability, IT service continuity, information security and demand management. It is designed to develop organizations’ and individuals’ understanding of the ITIL Service Design processes and help ensure that new and updated services, service management systems and tools, technology architecture, processes and measurement systems, methods and metrics are designed to meet user needs and will require little further change once introduced.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry give a general overview of what to expect in the upcoming ITIL PPO series. They cover topics like who is the intended audience, what the scope of the series will cover, and what are some specific topics that will be addressed.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.924
[SOUND]
>> In this segment, we're

2
00:00:04.924 --> 00:00:08.994
gonna take a brief look at what you can
expect from our upcoming ITIL PPO series,

3
00:00:08.994 --> 00:00:11.580
and joining us in the studio is Mr.
Terry Decker.

4
00:00:11.580 --> 00:00:14.260
Terry, can you give us
a brief introduction or

5
00:00:14.260 --> 00:00:17.390
just an overview of what we
can expect in that series?

6
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:22.342
>> Well, PPO, Planning Protection &
Optimization is one of the capability

7
00:00:22.342 --> 00:00:26.036
modules designed by the ITIL
accredited curriculum and

8
00:00:26.036 --> 00:00:28.090
it focuses on five processes.

9
00:00:29.220 --> 00:00:32.480
Capacity management, availability
management, continuity management,

10
00:00:32.480 --> 00:00:35.190
security management and demand management.

11
00:00:35.190 --> 00:00:39.060
Those five processes, four of them
that is, come from service design,

12
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:41.140
one of them comes from service strategy.

13
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:45.520
And it looks at those in a combined way;
how they interact with each other, and

14
00:00:45.520 --> 00:00:49.110
dives deep into the specific
activities of each of those processes.

15
00:00:49.110 --> 00:00:49.620
>> Excellent, now,

16
00:00:49.620 --> 00:00:53.975
could you give us an idea of who the
intended audience for this exam would be?

17
00:00:53.975 --> 00:00:58.295
Well, one, yeah, one key audience
member is going to be someone

18
00:00:58.295 --> 00:01:02.125
perhaps on the path of getting
their ITIL expert credential.

19
00:01:02.125 --> 00:01:04.835
This is a capability module,
it's worth four credits, so

20
00:01:04.835 --> 00:01:09.175
if you pass that exam you get four credits
toward the collection of credits you need

21
00:01:09.175 --> 00:01:13.355
to sit the Capstone exam which is called,
Managing Across the Life Cycles.

22
00:01:13.355 --> 00:01:17.500
So four credits await with successful
completion of the exam and

23
00:01:17.500 --> 00:01:20.650
operationally speaking, the audience
is gonna be those that are involved in

24
00:01:20.650 --> 00:01:24.530
strategic and design activities for
the IT service organization.

25
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:27.440
So demand management
plays out in strategy,

26
00:01:27.440 --> 00:01:31.470
the other four play out in design as
relates to planning, protection and

27
00:01:31.470 --> 00:01:34.980
optimization, you really are trying
to build effective services

28
00:01:34.980 --> 00:01:40.230
that are resilient to change, and
are capable of growing with the business.

29
00:01:40.230 --> 00:01:45.002
So business focus, service designed
activities is the primary focus of PPO.

30
00:01:45.002 --> 00:01:49.392
>> Excellent, and now we have an idea
of who might be watching this.

31
00:01:49.392 --> 00:01:52.670
Obviously, there's exam takes
who are part of that group.

32
00:01:52.670 --> 00:01:56.130
When it comes to the exams, could you
give us an idea of what is like to

33
00:01:56.130 --> 00:02:00.120
get registered or just what it's
gonna be like to take the exam.

34
00:02:00.120 --> 00:02:05.390
>> Well, I'm here, I represent PassionIT
Group which is a portal passionitgroup.com

35
00:02:05.390 --> 00:02:08.490
you can go there and get information
about exams at a very specific level,

36
00:02:08.490 --> 00:02:13.000
you can order your exam vouchers there at
a discount and through PassionIT Group,

37
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:16.780
you also get access to other
resources like course materials.

38
00:02:16.780 --> 00:02:19.370
As you sign up for this course,
as you're taking the curriculum,

39
00:02:19.370 --> 00:02:23.630
there is a wealth of information
in a zip file that has exam prep,

40
00:02:25.280 --> 00:02:29.690
activities, knowledge check activities,
as well as specific instructions for

41
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:32.930
how you get those vouchers ordered and
how you get your exam scheduled.

42
00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:36.290
The exam itself is a little bit different
than the foundation exam If you've

43
00:02:36.290 --> 00:02:39.770
had an intermediate Excel book exam
before you'll find it very similar.

44
00:02:39.770 --> 00:02:43.230
They're scenario based questions,
only eight of them, and

45
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:47.930
they're gradient scoring, meaning that one
answer will give you five points of value.

46
00:02:47.930 --> 00:02:51.690
Another answer will give you three,
other answers will give you less, right?

47
00:02:51.690 --> 00:02:53.590
So you've got to pick a better answer.

48
00:02:53.590 --> 00:02:55.150
You're analyzing things.

49
00:02:55.150 --> 00:02:58.350
So these intermediate level
exams are not rote memorization,

50
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:01.620
they are taking knowledge and applying it,
which make it pretty fun actually.

51
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:02.470
>> Very, very cool.

52
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:04.809
Well Terry, we do thank you for
that information and

53
00:03:04.809 --> 00:03:07.309
if that sounds like something
that might interest you,

54
00:03:07.309 --> 00:03:09.722
we look forward to seeing
you in the up coming series.

55
00:03:09.722 --> 00:03:13.284
[SOUND]

ITIL planning protection and

12
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:33.480
How's it going today?

13
00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:34.510
>> It's going great.

14

Those four processes happen to come

And also demand management, which

00:01:09.885 --> 00:01:10.715

And we're also going to get involved

00:01:18.055 --> 00:01:20.145

30
00:01:20.145 --> 00:01:23.615
And as we discuss those many

So as you look at, consider about

00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:43.975
the next slide deals

a higher level than what your

00:02:12.740 --> 00:02:14.490
So it's scenario based.

00:02:17.370 --> 00:02:20.280
So you're not gonna be asked

00:02:21.380 --> 00:02:23.920

00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:25.320
>> That sounds like my kind of exam.

00:02:30.450 --> 00:02:33.749

00:02:33.749 --> 00:02:35.266
You're solving a puzzle.

00:02:35.266 --> 00:02:38.435
So not rote memorization,

00:02:38.435 --> 00:02:43.825
Which can be a good experience for

00:02:43.825 --> 00:02:48.260
They are more, I would say probably a bit

56
00:02:48.260 --> 00:02:52.730
but that foundation was pretty tough, and

00:02:52.730 --> 00:02:56.430
a little bit of lecture and

58
00:02:56.430 --> 00:03:00.240
So that could be a lot harder sometimes

59
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:02.830
But that's the nature of this beast,

00:03:02.830 --> 00:03:07.380
So the way we're going to approach this is

00:03:13.040 --> 00:03:16.320
There's opportunities for

There's also plenty of opportunities for

00:03:23.700 --> 00:03:27.790
Don't just take the lectures, but go try

00:03:27.790 --> 00:03:31.260
There are some exercises we prepared for

00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:34.340
And as well as some knowledge checks,

00:03:39.290 --> 00:03:41.600

00:03:45.465 --> 00:03:49.423
tricks on how you can get in the mind

72
00:03:50.635 --> 00:03:52.945
All these resources that we just
mentioned, well, except for

73
00:03:52.945 --> 00:03:58.310
the lecture and discussions,

74
00:03:58.310 --> 00:04:02.610
please go right now to the show
files up above me here and

00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:07.380
download the zip file, and when you unzip

00:04:07.380 --> 00:04:10.780
including these exercises that will

77
00:04:10.780 --> 00:04:12.390
So speaking of exams and preparing for

First of all this is an accredited course.

00:04:23.780 --> 00:04:24.590

00:04:29.370 --> 00:04:34.150

exam organizations, exam institutes.

00:04:39.430 --> 00:04:42.620

00:04:42.620 --> 00:04:46.880

00:04:46.880 --> 00:04:49.180
in partnership with ITProTV, so

00:04:49.180 --> 00:04:52.860

00:05:05.640 --> 00:05:10.790

00:05:10.790 --> 00:05:12.551
>> Nobody's getting turned

00:05:12.551 --> 00:05:13.284
>> That's right.

00:05:13.284 --> 00:05:14.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exactly right.

97
00:05:14.330 --> 00:05:18.260
>> So here is this little house just
basically describes all the course work

98
00:05:18.260 --> 00:05:20.770
that's possible through
the ITIL curriculum,

99
00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:24.350
as blessed by the copyright owner and
the exam institutes.

100
00:05:24.350 --> 00:05:28.760
You see at the bottom there,
we're two credits is ITIL Foundation.

101
00:05:30.000 --> 00:05:31.715
It's available on ITProTV and

00:05:31.715 --> 00:05:36.760
ITIL Foundation is a course that is
a prerequisite for all the courses.

103
00:05:36.760 --> 00:05:40.020
In other words,
before you can sit any other exams,

104
00:05:40.020 --> 00:05:42.350
you have to earn
the ITIL Foundation certificate.

105
00:05:42.350 --> 00:05:46.350

you gotta start at the foundation.

106
00:05:46.350 --> 00:05:50.440
Now after you get foundation
your path is very elective.

107
00:05:50.440 --> 00:05:53.340
You can choose lots of different
courses from either side here.

00:05:53.340 --> 00:05:56.389
You'll see that ITIL
practitioner is available and

00:05:56.389 --> 00:05:58.480
offers you three credits, right?

00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:01.540
Other courses offer you three,
you see on there oo the left.

Some courses offer you four.

00:06:03.380 --> 00:06:06.520
If you collect enough credits
a total of 22 credits,

114
00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:12.170
Assuming that foundation is

management across the life cycle, the

116
00:06:16.660 --> 00:06:20.360
Okay, so where we are for
this course is there with PPO.

117
00:06:20.360 --> 00:06:23.010
You see it there along
the right side there.

118
00:06:23.010 --> 00:06:24.460
Planning, protection, and optimization.

119
00:06:25.870 --> 00:06:29.310
These form the capability modules,

120
00:06:29.310 --> 00:06:34.020
which are really a collection
of topics from the core books.

00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:36.180
On the left, you have just the core books.

00:06:36.180 --> 00:06:40.830

service transition, service operations and

123
00:06:40.830 --> 00:06:42.240
continuous service improvement.

00:06:42.240 --> 00:06:46.560
Those life cycle modules
correspond one-to-one to

125
00:06:46.560 --> 00:06:50.920
each of the core publications
published by ITIL.

126
00:06:50.920 --> 00:06:54.010
So, life cycle modules get
you three credits each,

127
00:06:54.010 --> 00:06:56.010
capability modules get
you four credits each.

128
00:06:56.010 --> 00:06:57.520
You can take them from either side.

129
00:06:57.520 --> 00:06:59.810
In other words,
after you've taken foundation,

00:06:59.810 --> 00:07:03.660
you could take service offerings

00:07:03.660 --> 00:07:05.980
Come over and
take service design and get three.

132
00:07:05.980 --> 00:07:09.420
Back over to release control and
validation for four more.

133
00:07:09.420 --> 00:07:11.710
Back over to service operations for three.

134
00:07:11.710 --> 00:07:13.480
You can mix and

135
00:07:13.480 --> 00:07:21.020
Once you've amassed 17 credits,

00:07:21.020 --> 00:07:25.750
You can then be eligible to set and take

00:07:25.750 --> 00:07:30.560

00:07:30.560 --> 00:07:33.420

00:07:33.420 --> 00:07:35.780
you're considered an ITIL expert.

To be an accredited trainer as I am,

you have to have that credential,

so in other words I'm teaching PPO,

00:07:49.400 --> 00:07:53.140
Not just all the rest of them, I had to
have PPO specifically in my curriculum.

00:07:53.140 --> 00:07:54.666
>> And that just kinda makes sense to me,
right.

00:07:54.666 --> 00:07:55.653
>> Well yeah, of course.

>> That's right.

So again to recap on the left here

00:08:04.110 --> 00:08:08.770
Those are one to one matching
to the core curriculum.

152
00:08:08.770 --> 00:08:13.080

153
00:08:13.080 --> 00:08:15.290
PPO itself, planning,
protection, optimization,

154
00:08:15.290 --> 00:08:20.920
draws a lot from service design and
picks up one process from server strategy.

155
00:08:20.920 --> 00:08:23.980
So it's taken from a combination of those.

156
00:08:23.980 --> 00:08:26.410
And they're applying these in
some sort of practical manner.

157
00:08:26.410 --> 00:08:28.800
So they're giving you some
very specific activities.

158
00:08:28.800 --> 00:08:31.980
They dive a little bit deeper
into what you have to do

00:08:31.980 --> 00:08:34.420
to be successful with
these particular processes

00:08:34.420 --> 00:08:39.590
rather than at the high level what
the processes accomplish okay, all right.

161
00:08:39.590 --> 00:08:44.650
So, moving forward here you'll see,
that where we are, is for

162
00:08:44.650 --> 00:08:47.880
the capability lifecycle
we're doing something.

163
00:08:47.880 --> 00:08:50.220
We're actually seeing
the activities involved, for

164
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:52.160
the service lifecycle approach.

165
00:08:52.160 --> 00:08:55.920
It's more about the strategy
of implementing these

166
00:08:55.920 --> 00:08:58.366
different life cycle stages and
the processes that they hold.

167
00:08:58.366 --> 00:09:02.025
Okay, all right.

168
00:09:02.025 --> 00:09:03.710
So the exam is different.

169
00:09:03.710 --> 00:09:07.770
As I mentioned before the foundation exam
is 40 questions of rote memorization with

170
00:09:07.770 --> 00:09:09.250
one correct answer.

171
00:09:09.250 --> 00:09:13.010
These intermediate level exams,
there's only 8 of them.

172
00:09:13.010 --> 00:09:17.480
And there is more than one correct answer.

173
00:09:17.480 --> 00:09:22.430
So for instance, one answer will give
you a maximum of 5 points, another

174
00:09:22.430 --> 00:09:26.080
answer would give you 3 points, another
answer, if you choose it, will give you 1.

175
00:09:26.080 --> 00:09:29.820
Of course, you can also pick
the distractor and get 0 credit for

176
00:09:29.820 --> 00:09:31.430
that particular question.

177
00:09:31.430 --> 00:09:34.990
So eight questions with
a possibility of five for

178
00:09:34.990 --> 00:09:36.770
each question means there's
a maximum of 40 points.

179
00:09:36.770 --> 00:09:40.710
All right,
you need to get 28 out of those 40.

180
00:09:40.710 --> 00:09:44.975
So you don't have to be absolutely
perfect to pass this exam.

181
00:09:44.975 --> 00:09:46.170
70% is where you're weighing in at.

182
00:09:46.170 --> 00:09:51.390
28 out of 40 that means that if you do
the math there, if you did six three point

183
00:09:51.390 --> 00:09:57.690
answers for 18, plus two five point
answers for ten, that's the 28.

184
00:09:57.690 --> 00:10:01.740
So what we need to get good at,
is getting rid of the ones and zeroes,

185
00:10:01.740 --> 00:10:04.840
stay in that wheelhouse of always being
able to pick the three and five answers.

186
00:10:04.840 --> 00:10:07.510
As you practice these exams and
as you're preparing for

187
00:10:07.510 --> 00:10:09.930
the exams, that's really what
you want to be targeting,

188
00:10:09.930 --> 00:10:12.960
is that nice little sweet spot
of picking three's and five's.

189
00:10:12.960 --> 00:10:16.620
Of course it'd be great
if you could get 100% and

190
00:10:16.620 --> 00:10:18.060
always get the five point answers.

191
00:10:18.060 --> 00:10:19.650
It'd be great.

192
00:10:19.650 --> 00:10:22.670
>> It really shows that they
have a focus on whether or

193
00:10:22.670 --> 00:10:23.890
not you understand the concept.

194
00:10:23.890 --> 00:10:27.250
And not so much well step one is this,
step two is this, or

195
00:10:27.250 --> 00:10:30.060
that rote answer is x, y, or z.

196
00:10:30.060 --> 00:10:33.310
Which can be very frustrating because,
you know exams.

197
00:10:33.310 --> 00:10:37.320
A lot of them, they're just testing on
how well you take a test and not so

198
00:10:37.320 --> 00:10:40.130
much on on how much that you
know about the material.

199
00:10:40.130 --> 00:10:43.580
This seems to really gear into
show us how much you do and

200
00:10:43.580 --> 00:10:46.663
you have a grading scale
in which you can do that.

201
00:10:46.663 --> 00:10:47.950
Agreed that's a good point Daniel.

202
00:10:47.950 --> 00:10:52.840
I've taken lots of different technology
exams over my years and as Daniel said

203
00:10:52.840 --> 00:10:58.090
some of them just see can you regurgitate
at a very deep level a particular concept.

204
00:10:58.090 --> 00:11:01.945
This is applying knowledge which
again I find a bit more fair.

205
00:11:01.945 --> 00:11:05.445
That said, there is an academic
notion to this exam as well.

206
00:11:05.445 --> 00:11:09.525
What I mean by that is, test makers
have to test against objectives.

207
00:11:09.525 --> 00:11:14.400
So, while they try to make it as realistic
as possible, some times the reality is not

208
00:11:14.400 --> 00:11:18.405
100% accurate because they have to test
an academic environment some what.

209
00:11:18.405 --> 00:11:20.785
So, we call that the ITIL island.

210
00:11:20.785 --> 00:11:23.365
One of the downloads available
to you is going to be

211
00:11:26.220 --> 00:11:29.100
basically a tutorial on
how to approach the exam.

212
00:11:29.100 --> 00:11:33.720
I highly encourage you to have a look
at that as it becomes available.

213
00:11:33.720 --> 00:11:35.970
And you'll get some of the nuance for

214
00:11:35.970 --> 00:11:40.510
how the test makers think about these
objectives, and how they should be tested.

215
00:11:40.510 --> 00:11:45.360
That concludes this set up and
logistics episode.

216
00:11:45.360 --> 00:11:50.760
Tune in soon for
a deep dive into foundation review.

217
00:11:50.760 --> 00:11:51.970
>> All right, Terry, great stuff.

218
00:11:51.970 --> 00:11:53.940
We do thank you for joining us today.

219
00:11:53.940 --> 00:11:56.910
Thank our good viewers for watching, but
it looks like that's our show for today.

220
00:11:56.910 --> 00:11:58.160
Definitely come back.

221
00:11:58.160 --> 00:12:00.310
Like Terry said,
we've got plenty more to go.

222
00:12:00.310 --> 00:12:01.980
So definitely join us for those.

223
00:12:01.980 --> 00:12:04.050
That being said,
it is time for us to sign off.

224
00:12:04.050 --> 00:12:08.350
We do appreciate you watching for IT Pro
TV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

225
00:12:08.350 --> 00:12:09.080
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

226
00:12:09.080 --> 00:12:13.447
>> We'll see you next time.

227
00:12:13.447 --> 00:12:17.132
[MUSIC]

228
00:12:17.132 --> 00:12:20.333
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry take time to review the ITIL Foundation content as the PPO exam leans heavily on that knowledge base. Here they quickly walk through the pertinent terms and concepts used in the PPO exam.
episodes.title: Foudation Refresher
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:06.261
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.261 --> 00:00:08.053
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.053 --> 00:00:12.045
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.045 --> 00:00:13.938
>> All right, greetings, everyone and

5
00:00:13.938 --> 00:00:16.257
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.257 --> 00:00:21.057
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode, we are continuing on with

7
00:00:21.057 --> 00:00:25.265
more on our ITIL PPO series,
the Planning Protection and Optimization.

8
00:00:25.265 --> 00:00:26.757
And of course,
joining us in the studio yet

9
00:00:26.757 --> 00:00:30.537
again, continuing to lend his expertise,
our good friend, Mr. Terry Decker.

10
00:00:30.537 --> 00:00:32.367
Terry, welcome back my man,
how's it going?

11
00:00:32.367 --> 00:00:34.007
>> Happy to be here, yep.

12
00:00:34.007 --> 00:00:38.166
Before we dive in too deeply into the
topics related to Planning Protection and

13
00:00:38.166 --> 00:00:42.010
Optimization, I wanna make sure that
we knock off the rusts of some basic

14
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:44.547
concepts that were
discovered in foundation.

15
00:00:44.547 --> 00:00:48.330
So, rather than necessarily taking
the whole foundation course again,

16
00:00:48.330 --> 00:00:52.660
tune in pretty specifically to this
particular module because it's going to

17
00:00:52.660 --> 00:00:55.280
help with the language of ITIL.

18
00:00:55.280 --> 00:00:58.950
It has its own definitions of things, so,
getting our head around that language

19
00:00:58.950 --> 00:01:01.900
again is gonna be pretty important for
future success.

20
00:01:01.900 --> 00:01:07.020
Again, you're not gonna be asked
explicit questions about these things,

21
00:01:07.020 --> 00:01:08.700
but they're gonna be using this language.

22
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:12.060
So, get your head around the language,
it's gonna be really helpful.

23
00:01:12.060 --> 00:01:14.040
So, this idea, man,
just an idea of some of these things,

24
00:01:14.040 --> 00:01:17.460
just a few questions here as we
look at this PowerPoint here.

25
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:21.170
Which of the following best
describes the concept of utility?

26
00:01:21.170 --> 00:01:23.330
Do you remember what utility is?

27
00:01:23.330 --> 00:01:25.299
I'll give you a second
to take a look at these.

28
00:01:31.714 --> 00:01:33.470
Daniel, might you have a guess?

29
00:01:33.470 --> 00:01:38.278
>> Yeah, I was looking at this and
just because of, I would wanna go with a.

30
00:01:38.278 --> 00:01:40.040
That's just my instinct there.

31
00:01:40.040 --> 00:01:41.430
>> It's a pretty darn good answer.

32
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:44.849
The ability to tailor a service
design package to a specific purpose.

33
00:01:45.980 --> 00:01:49.810
Certainly, utility is intended
to be fit for purpose, so,

34
00:01:49.810 --> 00:01:52.260
it's a pretty good answer,
but it's not the best answer.

35
00:01:52.260 --> 00:01:56.230
The textbook definition is service
provision that removes constraints and

36
00:01:56.230 --> 00:01:57.300
enhances performance.

37
00:01:59.510 --> 00:02:01.290
So, it's basically the functionality.

38
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:04.960
We'll look at it a little bit later on and
review it more in depth, but

39
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:07.280
that's just the nature of
the beast about this language.

40
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:09.040
A very good answer in a,

41
00:02:09.040 --> 00:02:12.090
the best answer being d in this
case because it's very specific.

42
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:14.550
So, as you would've taken
an intermediate level exam, but

43
00:02:14.550 --> 00:02:16.490
I'm not gonna ask you
a question like this.

44
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:21.150
They'll just use the term, utility,
or they'll use the synonyms.

45
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:23.934
Like you're providing a service
that removes constraints and

46
00:02:23.934 --> 00:02:27.805
enhance the performance, but the users
are complaining about the warranty, right?

47
00:02:27.805 --> 00:02:33.270
So, it's basically a mix of the languages
there could play out for you.

48
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:35.040
Okay, how about another,
take a step at this one.

49
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:39.290
Which of the following
make up service assets?

50
00:02:39.290 --> 00:02:41.801
Basically, what is the definition
of a service asset?

51
00:02:55.502 --> 00:03:00.700
Again, as a textbook definition,
it's resources and capabilities.

52
00:03:00.700 --> 00:03:05.280
These other ones have some merit, but
according to ITIL, redefining the language

53
00:03:05.280 --> 00:03:10.080
in their own light, is a service asset
is either resource or capability.

54
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:12.600
Again, we'll have a look at these in
a little bit more detail later on.

55
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:15.810
I think it is kind of reinforcing
the need for a refresher here, right.

56
00:03:15.810 --> 00:03:20.701
And finally, which of the following
is an incorrect use of a RACI chart?

57
00:03:22.381 --> 00:03:23.318
Incorrect use.

58
00:03:25.754 --> 00:03:28.380
So, does it define roles and
responsibilities?

59
00:03:28.380 --> 00:03:31.940
Yeah, does it determine
who should be consulted?

60
00:03:31.940 --> 00:03:34.300
That's what the C stands for,
so that's good.

61
00:03:34.300 --> 00:03:37.820
To ensure sufficient people
are responsible for each activity?

62
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:40.500
That's correct.

63
00:03:40.500 --> 00:03:43.240
To ensure more than one
person is accountable?

64
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:45.050
That's incorrect, so, therefore,

65
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:49.470
D is the correct answer because
it is incorrect use of a RACI.

66
00:03:49.470 --> 00:03:52.970
According to RACI, there's only one
accountable for any given activity.

67
00:03:54.700 --> 00:03:58.480
So again, the need for
reinforcement is what this was about, and

68
00:03:58.480 --> 00:04:00.200
we're gonna do that reinforcement now.

69
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:01.980
The things we learned in foundation.

70
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:05.576
>> So, if we're not just coming off
the heels of our foundations exam,

71
00:04:05.576 --> 00:04:09.422
we probably gonna wanna pay attention
to those foundation foundations.

72
00:04:09.422 --> 00:04:11.190
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, exactly right.

73
00:04:11.190 --> 00:04:14.987
Again, not only to knock off the rust
of the conceptual things cuz maybe,

74
00:04:14.987 --> 00:04:18.000
that is kind of embedded, but
it's the language things.

75
00:04:18.000 --> 00:04:19.680
>> Yeah,
that terminology will get you every time.

76
00:04:19.680 --> 00:04:20.786
>> Yeah, they would,
it's just terminology.

77
00:04:20.786 --> 00:04:22.141
>> You're not on top of that stuff and

78
00:04:22.141 --> 00:04:24.714
they start asking you questions
based off of their definition and

79
00:04:24.714 --> 00:04:27.210
you don't have that,
you're gonna be in a real world of hurt.

80
00:04:27.210 --> 00:04:29.870
>> Exactly right, so,
we'll certainly do the concepts and

81
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:33.210
we'll also get into some
of the words as well.

82
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:35.737
So, this whole idea of a lifecycle,

83
00:04:35.737 --> 00:04:40.800
you'll recall from foundation that
ITIL is based on service lifecycle.

84
00:04:40.800 --> 00:04:44.311
So, Daniel,
what does lifecycle mean to you?

85
00:04:44.311 --> 00:04:45.480
Just generically.

86
00:04:45.480 --> 00:04:49.510
>> Just generically,
I would say it is the start to finish

87
00:04:49.510 --> 00:04:52.940
procedure that you're gonna go through for
any given task.

88
00:04:52.940 --> 00:04:55.535
>> Exactly, good choice.

89
00:04:55.535 --> 00:04:57.980
Lifecycle could be applied to so
many different things.

90
00:04:57.980 --> 00:05:02.255
Lifecycle of an employee from the time
their hired to the time they're fired or

91
00:05:02.255 --> 00:05:02.854
retired.

92
00:05:02.854 --> 00:05:04.621
>> Retired [LAUGH]
>> Exactly right, or

93
00:05:04.621 --> 00:05:06.460
in those points in-between.

94
00:05:06.460 --> 00:05:08.490
So, the lifecycle of employee.

95
00:05:08.490 --> 00:05:12.210
The lifecycle of an incident in ITIL.

96
00:05:12.210 --> 00:05:13.860
From the time the person calls and

97
00:05:13.860 --> 00:05:18.740
says, I can't find the application,
the application seems to be down,

98
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:21.350
to the time it's restored, and
that user is satisfied again.

99
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:23.530
The lifecycle of an incident, right?

100
00:05:23.530 --> 00:05:28.960
So the nature of ITIL is based
on the lifecycle of a service,

101
00:05:28.960 --> 00:05:33.440
that a service has a lifecycle from the
idea that the services needs to be brought

102
00:05:33.440 --> 00:05:37.710
to life through the design transition

103
00:05:37.710 --> 00:05:43.110
in operation of that service and
the ongoing improvement of that service.

104
00:05:43.110 --> 00:05:45.830
Ultimately, the service
could be retired as well.

105
00:05:45.830 --> 00:05:48.500
So this idea of a lifecycle is in play,
and

106
00:05:48.500 --> 00:05:51.700
ITIL, describing
the lifecycle of a service.

107
00:05:51.700 --> 00:05:54.650
And it's based on five core books

108
00:05:54.650 --> 00:06:00.070
that coincide with five stages in
a lifecycle service, such as these.

109
00:06:00.070 --> 00:06:04.850
So you have Service Strategy, the earliest
stage in the lifecycle of a service.

110
00:06:06.400 --> 00:06:10.607
Service Design, which we're gonna spend
a lot of time discussing through PPO.

111
00:06:10.607 --> 00:06:15.452
Planning Protection and
Optimization draws from processes

112
00:06:15.452 --> 00:06:21.010
that are described in the service
design core book, all right.

113
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:24.450
Service Transition,
to bring the design to life and

114
00:06:24.450 --> 00:06:27.840
make it something that's breathable and
workable.

115
00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:30.650
And then, Service Operation
is the day-to-day caring and

116
00:06:30.650 --> 00:06:34.550
feeding of the service
serving the customers.

117
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:37.600
CSI, Continual Service Improvement
is a lifecycle stage

118
00:06:37.600 --> 00:06:40.270
that is actually embedded
in all stages and

119
00:06:40.270 --> 00:06:46.830
it's a continual cycle of improvement of
the services through measured improvement.

120
00:06:46.830 --> 00:06:50.469
Again, we're gonna spend a lot of
time talking about Service Design.

121
00:06:51.700 --> 00:06:53.920
You'll see, and
what's highlighted here in blue,

122
00:06:53.920 --> 00:06:58.240
are the five processes we're
gonna be talking about in PPO.

123
00:06:58.240 --> 00:07:00.110
Four of which are coming
from Service Design.

124
00:07:01.760 --> 00:07:05.790
In addition to the warranty processes,
as they're referred to, capacity,

125
00:07:05.790 --> 00:07:10.910
availability, continuity, and
security management, we're gonna add

126
00:07:10.910 --> 00:07:16.070
to the discussion Demand Management, which
happens to be located in Service Strategy.

127
00:07:16.070 --> 00:07:21.876
As you can see, these processes
are associated with each stage.

128
00:07:21.876 --> 00:07:26.430
And while we can talk about them
separately, they certainly interact.

129
00:07:26.430 --> 00:07:32.500
It would be folly for design people not
to understand the transition processes.

130
00:07:32.500 --> 00:07:36.737
It would be silly for transition people
to not understand design processes,

131
00:07:36.737 --> 00:07:39.423
strategy processes, operational processes.

132
00:07:39.423 --> 00:07:43.575
So while they're discussed
in these different stages,

133
00:07:43.575 --> 00:07:47.726
they are absolutely integrated and
tend to be integrated

134
00:07:47.726 --> 00:07:52.411
across the various functions and
people that practice, okay?

135
00:07:52.411 --> 00:07:56.101
All right, so,
again some more definitions.

136
00:07:56.101 --> 00:07:56.996
What is a service?

137
00:07:56.996 --> 00:07:58.316
Textbook definition.

138
00:07:58.316 --> 00:08:01.310
A means of delivering value to Customers.

139
00:08:01.310 --> 00:08:03.200
Notice the all caps there.

140
00:08:03.200 --> 00:08:07.970
A means of delivering value to
customers by facilitating outcomes

141
00:08:07.970 --> 00:08:12.580
that they want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

142
00:08:12.580 --> 00:08:15.630
The basis of ITIL is service.

143
00:08:15.630 --> 00:08:18.480
Not solutions, not systems.

144
00:08:18.480 --> 00:08:22.420
It's one thing to deliver a system or
an application.

145
00:08:22.420 --> 00:08:24.980
It's another thing to deliver a service

146
00:08:24.980 --> 00:08:29.070
which could be underpinned
certainly by various things, but

147
00:08:29.070 --> 00:08:33.590
service is a lot more holistic way to look
at what you're providing to customers.

148
00:08:35.110 --> 00:08:38.290
Focus again on these words value and
customer.

149
00:08:38.290 --> 00:08:43.280
I call it the nine tenths rule in
the foundation course where if you

150
00:08:43.280 --> 00:08:49.360
have an answer that includes the word
value, and the other three answers don't,

151
00:08:49.360 --> 00:08:53.270
chances are the answer that includes
value is the correct answer.

152
00:08:53.270 --> 00:08:56.610
The same goes true for the word customers.

153
00:08:56.610 --> 00:09:01.060
If you have four answers,
one seems to have a focus a on customers.

154
00:09:01.060 --> 00:09:04.910
Other ones don't have the focus on
customers, the one that has the focus on

155
00:09:04.910 --> 00:09:09.480
customers is very likely the better
answer on intermediate exam.

156
00:09:09.480 --> 00:09:12.310
So again, nine times out of ten,

157
00:09:12.310 --> 00:09:17.750
if a answer includes value or
customers and the other answers don't.

158
00:09:17.750 --> 00:09:19.080
Chances are the one with value and

159
00:09:19.080 --> 00:09:21.220
customers is going to
be the better answer.

160
00:09:21.220 --> 00:09:27.230
That's just how important these things,
these concepts are in ITIL, all right.

161
00:09:27.230 --> 00:09:30.340

00:22:48.200 --> 00:22:50.460
I remember the advent of e-mail and

398
00:22:50.460 --> 00:22:55.110
at first it was just, within the office,
I could email my office mates.

399
00:22:57.030 --> 00:23:00.896
Of course Internet email broadens-
>> Expands that, yeah,

400
00:23:00.896 --> 00:23:01.865
>> So again,

401
00:23:01.865 --> 00:23:06.970
we are still enhancing
performance when we do that.

402
00:23:06.970 --> 00:23:11.080
Now I can communicate with thousands and
thousands of people.

403
00:23:11.080 --> 00:23:17.170
So, But even then, okay, so
now I get in an email at work, nice.

404
00:23:17.170 --> 00:23:22.780
But I had to be at work on a company
device, on a company desktop or

405
00:23:22.780 --> 00:23:26.470
laptop, connected to that network,

406
00:23:26.470 --> 00:23:29.880
They kinda broke down that particular
constraint by letting me have VPN

00:23:29.880 --> 00:23:31.150
access, right.

408
00:23:31.150 --> 00:23:31.674
>> Mm-hm.
>> So

409
00:23:31.674 --> 00:23:35.980
I still had to connect to my
network back at the office right?

410
00:23:35.980 --> 00:23:38.310
Through my internet connection.

411
00:23:38.310 --> 00:23:41.910
But through that VPN connection I
remove the constrain of having to be

00:23:41.910 --> 00:23:44.030
at the office physically.

413
00:23:44.030 --> 00:23:46.690
Right, and then that constraint
was eventually removed.

414
00:23:46.690 --> 00:23:51.055
Didn't even require VPN connection, of
course you can reach out your phone right

00:23:51.055 --> 00:23:53.406
now and
be able to check your email, right?

00:23:53.406 --> 00:23:54.557
So another constraint removed.

417
00:23:54.557 --> 00:23:56.935
The same performance is being supported,

00:23:56.935 --> 00:24:00.111
you're supporting the performance

00:24:00.111 --> 00:24:03.690
But now we remove the constraints of,

00:24:03.690 --> 00:24:06.430
Well now you can be on
your laptop at home to,

00:24:06.430 --> 00:24:09.360
I can get this from the beach on my phone,

00:24:09.360 --> 00:24:12.790
So that's removing constraints,
aspect of utility.

00:24:12.790 --> 00:24:16.590
It's basically the functionality
of removing constraints or

00:24:16.590 --> 00:24:17.950
enhancing performance.

00:24:17.950 --> 00:24:20.780
And it's also associated with

00:24:20.780 --> 00:24:27.390
You go full screen here, you'll see that

00:24:27.390 --> 00:24:32.550
You'll see that warranty is

00:24:32.550 --> 00:24:35.310

00:24:36.760 --> 00:24:39.820
Overall, it's saying that you

00:24:39.820 --> 00:24:42.070

00:24:42.070 --> 00:24:46.780
If you can do that, you're able to deliver

00:24:51.020 --> 00:24:55.470

00:24:55.470 --> 00:24:59.570

We're also going to throw in

But these warranty processes

00:25:12.290 --> 00:25:14.782

00:25:14.782 --> 00:25:19.870
it is is it there to be able to

00:25:20.980 --> 00:25:27.630

00:25:27.630 --> 00:25:31.970

00:25:31.970 --> 00:25:35.100

00:25:39.580 --> 00:25:43.640
But if it falls over everyday,

00:25:43.640 --> 00:25:48.100
>> Yeah warranty seems very

00:25:48.100 --> 00:25:49.470
Is it doing this, yes or no?

449
00:25:49.470 --> 00:25:51.310
Does it do this, yes or no?

00:25:51.310 --> 00:25:54.880
Whereas the utility seems

00:25:54.880 --> 00:25:55.870
Right-
>> Right, gives you more-

00:25:55.870 --> 00:25:56.720
>> And do you like it,

00:25:56.720 --> 00:25:58.870
right it's more, yeah, good point.

454
00:25:58.870 --> 00:26:02.320
It's more subjective,
utility's almost more subjective.

455
00:26:02.320 --> 00:26:04.990
Does it do it nicely, is it easy to use?

456
00:26:04.990 --> 00:26:06.930
Are you selling more

00:26:06.930 --> 00:26:08.136
>> Right.
>> Those kinds of things,

00:26:08.136 --> 00:26:09.490
whereas warranty is, is it there?

00:26:09.490 --> 00:26:10.400
>> Yes, or no?
>> Yeah.

460
00:26:10.400 --> 00:26:12.390
>> Right, is it secure, yes or no?

00:26:12.390 --> 00:26:13.810
Does it have sufficient capacity?

462
00:26:13.810 --> 00:26:17.280
Does it have sufficient security or

463
00:26:17.280 --> 00:26:19.670
So we're gonna talk deeply
about these later on, so

464
00:26:19.670 --> 00:26:22.650
I'm not gonna pick these

00:26:22.650 --> 00:26:25.880
But let's look at warranty,
at least in compare and contrast.

466
00:26:27.000 --> 00:26:32.260
They're all really somehow related to,
is it available, right?

467
00:26:32.260 --> 00:26:35.840
Availability is kind of
a baseline measurement of,

468
00:26:35.840 --> 00:26:38.090
is it there when it's
supposed to be there?

469
00:26:38.090 --> 00:26:41.650
Now availability could be
tarnished because of bad capacity.

470
00:26:41.650 --> 00:26:46.740
If the disk runs out of disk space and
the application falls over,

471
00:26:46.740 --> 00:26:50.711
that's a capacity issue that
affected availability, right?

472
00:26:50.711 --> 00:26:55.510
Continuity, continuities also
could effect availability.

473
00:26:55.510 --> 00:26:59.300
Continuity management is making
sure that if there is a failure,

474
00:26:59.300 --> 00:27:01.740
you can respond appropriately.

475
00:27:01.740 --> 00:27:05.960
Meaning quickly enough or cost effectively
enough, to bring the service back up.

476
00:27:05.960 --> 00:27:10.160
So if a server falls over dead,
is there any other server

477
00:27:10.160 --> 00:27:13.770
in the closet you can bring up and
be restored within two hours?

478
00:27:13.770 --> 00:27:16.630
Or is there one operating right
next to it, in real time?

479
00:27:16.630 --> 00:27:19.570
So if it falls over,
you're still up, right?

480
00:27:19.570 --> 00:27:21.790
That's continuity management,
dealing with this failure.

481
00:27:21.790 --> 00:27:25.140
Or what about losing
an entire data center, right?

482
00:27:25.140 --> 00:27:29.270
If a tornado strikes your data center,
how quickly can you recover from that?

483
00:27:29.270 --> 00:27:31.960
Do you have a redundant data
center in another geographic

484
00:27:31.960 --> 00:27:33.670
location that's ready to turn on?

485
00:27:33.670 --> 00:27:35.070
Is it already on?

486
00:27:35.070 --> 00:27:37.740
Those types of things is
what continuity deals with.

487
00:27:37.740 --> 00:27:40.020
But still points back to
the same question of,

488
00:27:40.020 --> 00:27:42.490
is it available when it's
supposed to be available, right?

489
00:27:42.490 --> 00:27:44.430
And then of course, security management.

490
00:27:44.430 --> 00:27:47.570
It could be available,
have plenty of availability designed in.

491
00:27:47.570 --> 00:27:50.280
It could have plenty of
capacity designed into it.

492
00:27:50.280 --> 00:27:53.450
Have a thorough continuity
plan designed for it.

493
00:27:53.450 --> 00:27:56.380
And then a denial of service
attack hits your network, and

494
00:27:56.380 --> 00:27:57.560
no one's getting anything.

495
00:27:57.560 --> 00:28:01.240
Or a virus attacks your network and
corrupts all the data, or deletes this and

496
00:28:01.240 --> 00:28:02.510
deletes that.

497
00:28:02.510 --> 00:28:07.890
Or anybody can get on the network,
due to a lack of security, and just starts

498
00:28:07.890 --> 00:28:10.700
putting fake information in there, or-

499
00:28:10.700 --> 00:28:12.210
>> Making it too available, exactly,

500
00:28:12.210 --> 00:28:14.190
making it available to everybody,
good point.

501
00:28:14.190 --> 00:28:15.790
So, security management.

502
00:28:15.790 --> 00:28:19.830
Not directly related to availability,
but related to the warranty.

503
00:28:19.830 --> 00:28:21.360
Is it performing as it should?

504
00:28:21.360 --> 00:28:23.620
And of course, if data gets corrupted, or

505
00:28:23.620 --> 00:28:28.530
if it's not available because of security
attacks or denial of service attacks.

506
00:28:28.530 --> 00:28:30.550
Then obviously you got an issue there.

507
00:28:30.550 --> 00:28:35.410
So, those four processes, availability,
capacity, continuity, and security.

508
00:28:35.410 --> 00:28:37.710
Those four processes are key to warranty.

509
00:28:37.710 --> 00:28:41.280
And they're also a big focus of
what we're gonna talk about in PPO.

510
00:28:41.280 --> 00:28:45.950
Planning, protection, and optimization,
focusing on those four processes.

511
00:28:45.950 --> 00:28:47.848
And again,
also throwing in some demand management.

512
00:28:47.848 --> 00:28:54.760
Okay, all right, assets,

00:28:54.760 --> 00:28:58.190
By definition,
an asset is a resource or capability.

It's interesting, because asset

00:29:04.840 --> 00:29:07.940
It's often considered,
in financial management,

00:29:07.940 --> 00:29:11.222
it's something that's got a tag on it,
on the laptop lid.

517
00:29:11.222 --> 00:29:13.830
And it has a depreciation
schedule associated with it.

518
00:29:13.830 --> 00:29:16.510
There are actually financial
things associated with assets.

519
00:29:16.510 --> 00:29:20.434
But ITIL's taken a word, it's commonly
used in different context, and

00:29:20.434 --> 00:29:22.345
given you a very specific meaning.

00:29:22.345 --> 00:29:25.750
And it simply means a resource or

Now, you may recall,
gonna ask you Daniel, if you recall,

00:29:29.343 --> 00:29:31.487

00:29:31.487 --> 00:29:35.447
>> Man, you're gonna [CROSSTALK]

00:29:35.447 --> 00:29:38.210

00:29:38.210 --> 00:29:41.890
As a service provider,
you have to consider your own assets.

00:29:43.017 --> 00:29:44.550
What other assets should you consider?

528
00:29:45.650 --> 00:29:48.900
>> This is why we're doing a foundation
refresher, because I don't remember.

529
00:29:48.900 --> 00:29:50.580
>> Exactly, fair enough,
I'm glad you don't.

00:29:50.580 --> 00:29:55.490
So you have customer assets and
service provider assets.

00:29:55.490 --> 00:29:58.250
Service assets are the ones
that you control,

00:29:58.250 --> 00:30:01.180
customer assets are the ones
you need to understand, right?

00:30:01.180 --> 00:30:03.680
So the way to kind of reinforce this.

00:30:03.680 --> 00:30:07.504
Do you have to be a geophysicist
to work in the IT

00:30:07.504 --> 00:30:09.042
department-

>> I'm kidding, I'm kidding,

it's not, I'm facetious here.

if you're working in the IT department of

00:30:28.730 --> 00:30:30.560
>> You need to understand
what those assets are doing.

00:30:30.560 --> 00:30:32.640

>> So they're bringing their expertise.

00:30:32.640 --> 00:30:34.930
You know, the customer assets,

00:30:34.930 --> 00:30:37.470
They have their resources and
their capabilities.

00:30:37.470 --> 00:30:40.340

00:30:40.340 --> 00:30:43.220

00:30:43.220 --> 00:30:47.610

Do what they did,

00:32:14.064 --> 00:32:15.090

00:32:25.500 --> 00:32:28.560
So considering customer assets, while you

00:32:39.930 --> 00:32:41.140

592
00:32:41.140 --> 00:32:44.750
So understanding customer assets,
their resources and capabilities.

00:32:44.750 --> 00:32:48.150

00:12:45.609 --> 00:12:47.125
>> Yeah, it's a joke about databases.

250
00:12:47.125 --> 00:12:49.355
>> My goodness,
good old database geek joke.

251
00:12:49.355 --> 00:12:51.695
I gotta check that one out, I'll be
sure to check it out, Bobby tables.

252
00:12:51.695 --> 00:12:54.243
Anyway, my team happened to drop

253
00:12:54.243 --> 00:12:58.797
operational databases three
times in about eight months.

254
00:12:58.797 --> 00:13:03.599
And of course, when you drop databases,
availability of the application kinda

255
00:13:03.599 --> 00:13:07.913
thanks, the application failed,
the service failed by us doing that.

256
00:13:07.913 --> 00:13:12.501
So it was effectively human error,
it wasn't technology failing.

257
00:13:12.501 --> 00:13:15.102
So again what did we do we do?

258
00:13:15.102 --> 00:13:18.222
The service owner was certainly knocking
on our heads, our doors I should say.

259
00:13:18.222 --> 00:13:19.577
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Knock on our door.

260
00:13:19.577 --> 00:13:21.852
>> Knocking on our heads
ends in a lawsuit.

261
00:13:21.852 --> 00:13:22.863
>> Bam, bam, bam, that's right.

262
00:13:22.863 --> 00:13:24.347
>> You can't do that.

263
00:13:24.347 --> 00:13:27.937
[LAUGH] They were knocking on our doors
saying why are we failing at availability?

264
00:13:27.937 --> 00:13:31.223
The first time it happened human error,
you can't correct it, right?

265
00:13:31.223 --> 00:13:34.719
Of course we could offset
the chance of that happening again.

266
00:13:34.719 --> 00:13:36.164
We didn't take that opportunity.

267
00:13:36.164 --> 00:13:39.935
After two more such activities we
kinda had to learn some lessons there.

268
00:13:39.935 --> 00:13:44.010
So again, availability management is
probably related to components and

269
00:13:44.010 --> 00:13:46.026
their failure but not necessarily.

270
00:13:46.026 --> 00:13:50.310
Things can fail because of
human activity as well.

271
00:13:50.310 --> 00:13:53.500
So availability management needs
to have that holistic view.

272
00:13:53.500 --> 00:13:55.448
How do you mitigate
the risk of human failure?

273
00:13:55.448 --> 00:13:59.401
How do you mitigate the risk of
technology failure in dealing with that?

274
00:13:59.401 --> 00:14:03.497
Okay, and the service owner, again,
is gonna have a key stake in that game.

275
00:14:03.497 --> 00:14:08.731
So, that wraps up our discussion
of the refresher for foundations.

276
00:14:08.731 --> 00:14:13.681
We are gonna get a little bit more

00:14:13.681 --> 00:14:16.913
up next with service
design considerations.

278
00:14:16.913 --> 00:14:19.676
>> Sounds great, sir,
we do thank you for joining us today.

279
00:14:19.676 --> 00:14:21.272

280
00:14:21.272 --> 00:14:24.734
But hopefully you are now going yes,
yeah, that's right, and

00:14:24.734 --> 00:14:26.714
this refresher has been great for you.

If not, hey just go back and

And then we can move

285
00:14:34.530 --> 00:14:36.444
Looking forward to doing

286
00:14:36.444 --> 00:14:39.845
So, thanks for joining us today,

287
00:14:39.845 --> 00:14:42.830
Signing off for ITProTV,

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.098
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.098 --> 00:00:10.608
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:10.608 --> 00:00:12.654
>> All right.

4
00:00:12.654 --> 00:00:13.680
Greetings everyone.

5
00:00:13.680 --> 00:00:17.000
Welcome to another great
episode of IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:17.000 --> 00:00:19.430
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:19.430 --> 00:00:23.620
we are coming back with more
On our ITIL PPO series.

8
00:00:23.620 --> 00:00:25.150
And joining us in the studio yet

9
00:00:25.150 --> 00:00:28.300
again to continue that conversation
our good friend, Mr. Terry Decker.

10
00:00:28.300 --> 00:00:29.210
Terry, welcome back, sir.

11
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:30.080
Good to have you again.

12
00:00:30.080 --> 00:00:31.330
>> Glad to be back.

13
00:00:31.330 --> 00:00:35.250
Yep, we're gonna need to set the stage
a little bit deeper about PPO, planning,

14
00:00:35.250 --> 00:00:36.610
protection and optimization.

15
00:00:37.630 --> 00:00:42.480
Setting the context of PPO within
the lifecycle stage called service design.

16
00:00:42.480 --> 00:00:47.600
Four of the five processes we're gonna
talk about through PPO are born and

17
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:50.320
raised in service design stage.

18
00:00:50.320 --> 00:00:53.750
Although active at other times in
other stages they are born here and

19
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:55.970
operate here most effectively.

20
00:00:55.970 --> 00:00:59.370
So certainly related to the planning and
protection aspect of it and

21
00:00:59.370 --> 00:01:00.920
ongoing optimization.

22
00:01:00.920 --> 00:01:06.120
Service design is the key stage that makes
sure those good questions are answered

23
00:01:06.120 --> 00:01:09.310
at the right time,
early in the lifetime of the service.

24
00:01:09.310 --> 00:01:12.300
So if we look at the slide deck here,
you'll see some reminders of these things

25
00:01:12.300 --> 00:01:17.270
that we learned about, in foundation as
well as perhaps intermediate courses.

26
00:01:18.420 --> 00:01:22.870
Service design is trying to fulfill
what service strategists have asked for.

27
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:25.260
And service strategists have asked for

28
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:29.040
a service to be designed to
meet certain business outcomes.

29
00:01:29.040 --> 00:01:32.310
So certainly making sure that
business requirements are met

30
00:01:32.310 --> 00:01:34.090
is what service design is about.

31
00:01:34.090 --> 00:01:38.190
And those requirements are often
born out in service strategy.

32
00:01:40.410 --> 00:01:44.250
Service design is also anticipating how
the service is going to be delivered

33
00:01:44.250 --> 00:01:44.960
in operation.

34
00:01:44.960 --> 00:01:46.780
So service delivery and

35
00:01:46.780 --> 00:01:51.150
service design are opposite sides
of the same coin in some regards.

36
00:01:51.150 --> 00:01:55.010
Whereas you anticipate how the service
is going to be delivered and

37
00:01:55.010 --> 00:01:57.410
therefore design it to that purpose.

38
00:01:57.410 --> 00:01:59.910
Let's take it away from IT services for
a little bit.

39
00:01:59.910 --> 00:02:03.420
Talk about service design unrelated to IT.

40
00:02:03.420 --> 00:02:08.480
For instance, how would you go about, if
your market strategy as a car manufacturer

41
00:02:08.480 --> 00:02:13.940
was to develop a new vehicle,
called an SUV, Circa 1984, right.

42
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:20.250
There was an SUV launched that year
by American Motors called the Jeep.

43
00:02:20.250 --> 00:02:23.190
It gained a lot of market shares, and
General Motors looks at that market share

44
00:02:23.190 --> 00:02:27.190
being taken up by this thing called SUV
and says, hey we need one of those things.

45
00:02:27.190 --> 00:02:28.450
Ford Motor Company does the same thing.

46
00:02:28.450 --> 00:02:30.560
It says, hey we need one of
those things called an SUV.

47
00:02:30.560 --> 00:02:31.654
>> They actually used to call them ORVs.

48
00:02:31.654 --> 00:02:33.790
Off road vehicles.

49
00:02:33.790 --> 00:02:35.340
>> Off road vehicles, right?

50
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:36.310
>> Now we call them SUV's.

51
00:02:36.310 --> 00:02:40.540
>> Sport utility, so you're going to be
on the road as well to provide sport and

52
00:02:40.540 --> 00:02:41.700
utility right?

53
00:02:41.700 --> 00:02:46.662
Get your groceries,
don't just jump stumps that's right.

54
00:02:46.662 --> 00:02:51.070
So this concept of an SUV was gaining
some steam in the market place.

55
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:53.510
Car manufacturer says hey
we need one of those.

56
00:02:53.510 --> 00:02:56.710
So service strategy says
we want one of those.

57
00:02:56.710 --> 00:02:57.530
What do you do?

58
00:02:57.530 --> 00:03:00.950
Well you design it,
you design this field, you prototype it,

59
00:03:00.950 --> 00:03:05.200
you make sure it's gonna be able to be
manufactured at a cost effective rate,

60
00:03:05.200 --> 00:03:07.890
can be supported at
a cost effective rates.

61
00:03:07.890 --> 00:03:11.050
The parts can be delivered,
the value chain,

62
00:03:11.050 --> 00:03:13.000
the supply chain can be
managed effectively.

63
00:03:13.000 --> 00:03:17.220
You got to manage your processes for
procurement of steel,

64
00:03:17.220 --> 00:03:19.130
and stamping, and all that sort of thing.

65
00:03:19.130 --> 00:03:24.850
So the idea of, let's have a new SUV,
something service strategy does.

66
00:03:24.850 --> 00:03:27.960
Service design's gonna come in here and
make it real, make it possible,

67
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:31.870
by answering all the questions that
need to be answered about manufacturing,

68
00:03:31.870 --> 00:03:35.930
delivering eventually to a show
room floor somewhere and

69
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:40.940
then ongoing support of that through
service and parts and what not.

70
00:03:40.940 --> 00:03:44.860
So service design is similar in that
you're anticipating what that's going to

71
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:47.870
be operations,
how is this gonna be delivered?

72
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:49.270
How is it going to be manufactured?

73
00:03:49.270 --> 00:03:50.260
What's the supply chain?

74
00:03:50.260 --> 00:03:52.020
What's the process chain?

75
00:03:52.020 --> 00:03:53.280
What's the point of interfaces?

76
00:03:53.280 --> 00:03:54.590
How do customers buy it?

77
00:03:54.590 --> 00:03:56.430
How do customers get it serviced?

78
00:03:56.430 --> 00:03:58.730
How they order parts,
all those sorts of things.

79
00:03:58.730 --> 00:04:03.000
And the different layers of stakeholders,
the car dealership versus the end user

80
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:08.750
customer, the distributors,
the manufacturers, the suppliers.

81
00:04:08.750 --> 00:04:11.340
Service design needs to
consider all those types of

82
00:04:11.340 --> 00:04:16.330
aspects to be able to deliver something
of value in operations later on.

83
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:19.440
So that’s really what service design
is about holistically, right.

84
00:04:19.440 --> 00:04:22.100
Understanding requirements,
making sure that the business requirement

85
00:04:22.100 --> 00:04:26.140
are understood well and
operating within some constraints.

86
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:28.123
All right, the constraints for

87
00:04:28.123 --> 00:04:32.540
regulatory constraints it has to be
safe it has to have seat belts in it.

88
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:36.780
There has to be appropriate fuel
consumption, perhaps mileage.

89
00:04:36.780 --> 00:04:39.320
Gas mileage is one of the constraints,
performance.

90
00:04:39.320 --> 00:04:42.040
Ground clearance might be one of
the things you're design constraints

91
00:04:42.040 --> 00:04:43.410
are operating under.

92
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:46.440
Does it have to be four-wheel drive,
two-wheel drive?

93
00:04:46.440 --> 00:04:50.310
So if you can take all those types
of considerations to an IT service,

94
00:04:50.310 --> 00:04:53.910
it is basically trying to reinforce
the idea that you need to think about

95
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:58.630
all the questions that need to be
answered before you get into operations,

96
00:04:58.630 --> 00:05:00.290
before the service is actually delivered.

97
00:05:00.290 --> 00:05:04.400
So you build it fit for purpose,
and fit for use, right.

98
00:05:04.400 --> 00:05:10.030
While operating within the constraints
of cost, of time, etc.

99
00:05:10.030 --> 00:05:11.380
Okay.

100
00:05:11.380 --> 00:05:14.590
So ultimately what service
design is trying to get done

101
00:05:14.590 --> 00:05:19.340
is to make sure you can reduce
total cost of ownership by

102
00:05:19.340 --> 00:05:23.890
making sure you don't have to fix
things after it's already launched.

103
00:05:23.890 --> 00:05:25.620
Hopefully it's working well.

104
00:05:25.620 --> 00:05:29.370
I'm sure that there's been occasions where
car manufactures have launched lemons

105
00:05:29.370 --> 00:05:33.390
that didn't meet the market expectations
and they had to get rid of I think-

106
00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:34.611
>> A Ford Pinto.

107
00:05:34.611 --> 00:05:37.736
[LAUGH]
>> I think Ford had an earlier one called

108
00:05:37.736 --> 00:05:40.930
the Edsel that was
famously under sold right?

109
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:43.000
They we're going to have a big
car that just kind of fell flat.

110
00:05:43.000 --> 00:05:46.210
>> They had that horse color on the-
>> Yeah well there was a lot of ugly

111
00:05:46.210 --> 00:05:47.110
vehicles back then.

112
00:05:47.110 --> 00:05:51.040
The big fins and things like that but
the Edsel perhaps was pretty disgusting.

113
00:05:51.040 --> 00:05:52.610
At any rate.

114
00:05:52.610 --> 00:05:55.750
>> As we insult all
the Edsel fans out there.

115
00:05:55.750 --> 00:05:59.280
>> Yeah exactly well if you have one
now it might be probably worth it.

116
00:05:59.280 --> 00:06:04.568
But at any rate service design is
trying to preclude that big surprise.

117
00:06:04.568 --> 00:06:08.630
You know what, no one really wants it but
answering all the questions as fitfully as

118
00:06:08.630 --> 00:06:13.050
possible before you actually launch is
really what its trying to get done.

119
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:16.010
And hopefully again the market is ready
for you, the customers are ready for

120
00:06:16.010 --> 00:06:18.010
you you're gonna fulfill a need.

121
00:06:18.010 --> 00:06:20.940
Right, you're going to perhaps
satisfy the regulators better.

122
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:24.490
You're gonna satisfy the bean
counters in accounting better.

123
00:06:24.490 --> 00:06:29.350
You're gonna satisfy both the cost
quality and risk factors better.

124
00:06:29.350 --> 00:06:30.350
That's what it's about.

125
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:33.120
And it relates to planning
protection optimization.

126
00:06:33.120 --> 00:06:34.850
The focus of this course.

127
00:06:34.850 --> 00:06:38.710
We're gonna be focusing a lot on making
sure that this service you're delivering

128
00:06:38.710 --> 00:06:40.010
has the appropriate warranty.

129
00:06:40.010 --> 00:06:42.370
That it's there when it's supposed to be.

130
00:06:42.370 --> 00:06:44.020
Not the functionality necessarily.

131
00:06:44.020 --> 00:06:46.830
Not gonna talk about the utility so
much as the warranty piece.

132
00:06:46.830 --> 00:06:50.630
We're not talking about intuitive
design of applications.

133
00:06:50.630 --> 00:06:51.910
We're talking about,

134
00:06:51.910 --> 00:06:56.130
is it designed because you anticipate
5,000 people using it everyday?

135
00:06:56.130 --> 00:07:02.260
Or 20,000 people using it everyday, or is
there other factors in play about usage?

136
00:07:02.260 --> 00:07:06.170
Maybe it's not used every day, but a bunch
of people use it at the end of the month,

137
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:10.400
answering all those kinds of questions is
what service design is trying to get done.

138
00:07:10.400 --> 00:07:15.975
Okay.
Of course, the target audience of service

139
00:07:15.975 --> 00:07:20.170
design is going to be the service
providers themselves.

140
00:07:21.210 --> 00:07:25.290
When we talk about these five processes,
availability management, capacity

141
00:07:25.290 --> 00:07:28.700
management, continuity management,
security management and demand management.

142
00:07:28.700 --> 00:07:31.930
We're going to be talking about what
the service provider is doing on behalf of

143
00:07:31.930 --> 00:07:32.860
the customer.

144
00:07:32.860 --> 00:07:35.880
In fact, a lot of service design happens

145
00:07:35.880 --> 00:07:38.550
in the background without
visibility to the customer.

146
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:41.110
There's certainly going to be some
interface with the customers for

147
00:07:41.110 --> 00:07:42.390
honing in on requirements,

148
00:07:42.390 --> 00:07:45.640
making sure they understand the market
place and those types of things.

149
00:07:45.640 --> 00:07:49.339
But for the most part, these things are
happening in the backend with the customer

150
00:07:49.339 --> 00:07:52.715
in mind, okay, for sure, and making
sure that ultimately you can deliver

151
00:07:52.715 --> 00:07:54.341
the right things at the right time.

152
00:07:57.263 --> 00:07:59.796
The people that would
benefit from good design or

153
00:07:59.796 --> 00:08:03.752
people involved in good design are IT
architects, technical architects,

154
00:08:03.752 --> 00:08:07.060
how to build the perfect machine so
to speak.

155
00:08:07.060 --> 00:08:10.160
But IT managers and
practitioners also involved here.

156
00:08:10.160 --> 00:08:12.930
Service owners care about it,
remember service owners accountable for

157
00:08:12.930 --> 00:08:14.760
the quality of their service?

158
00:08:14.760 --> 00:08:18.290
Certainly service design can be good and

159
00:08:18.290 --> 00:08:20.890
therefore provide a good service or
it could be bad and

160
00:08:20.890 --> 00:08:24.580
the service falls over often,
not making service owners very happy.

161
00:08:24.580 --> 00:08:25.710
Right?
And of course business

162
00:08:25.710 --> 00:08:26.510
relationship managers.

163
00:08:26.510 --> 00:08:30.780
They're gonna be involved in that front
end interface with the customers,

164
00:08:30.780 --> 00:08:33.220
trying to find out what is
that's going to excite them.

165
00:08:33.220 --> 00:08:36.260
What it's the gotta haves as
opposed to nice to haves.

166
00:08:36.260 --> 00:08:37.710
What are they willing to spend?

167
00:08:37.710 --> 00:08:39.820
What's their cost tolerance?

168
00:08:39.820 --> 00:08:41.310
What's their risk tolerance?

169
00:08:41.310 --> 00:08:45.000
Are there regulatory over compelling
regulatory requirements means

170
00:08:45.000 --> 00:08:47.650
well we've got to spend it because if
we don't, we're gonna get audited and

171
00:08:47.650 --> 00:08:49.480
get shut down, that kind of thing.

172
00:08:49.480 --> 00:08:54.050
So it's like you can't have
an automobile that doesn't have brakes.

173
00:08:54.050 --> 00:08:56.560
So making sure that you have
all the safety features or

174
00:08:56.560 --> 00:08:59.860
regulatory features that are required for
a given service.

175
00:09:02.680 --> 00:09:03.585
Okay, all right,

176
00:09:03.585 --> 00:09:07.500
now this puts service design in context of
the other four stages in the lifecycle.

177
00:09:07.500 --> 00:09:08.890
You see it near the top.

178
00:09:08.890 --> 00:09:11.750
You got service strategy
up there at the top, right?

179
00:09:11.750 --> 00:09:13.250
So I'll get my laser pointer going here.

180
00:09:14.970 --> 00:09:19.310
You see that service strategy is
the earliest stage listed here and

181
00:09:19.310 --> 00:09:22.310
this is a great way to describe
kind of the downward flow.

182
00:09:22.310 --> 00:09:24.170
Once you've determined
what the strategy is,

183
00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:29.240
what services you wanna offer, do you
want to offer an SUV or an Edsel right?

184
00:09:29.240 --> 00:09:31.640
What do you want to offer as a service?

185
00:09:31.640 --> 00:09:35.160
You then need to approve
the appropriate funding,

186
00:09:35.160 --> 00:09:39.140
allocate the appropriate resources
in terms of people and time, and

187
00:09:39.140 --> 00:09:43.650
set the direction of the overarching
organization, right.

188
00:09:43.650 --> 00:09:47.740
So you pass those requirements
down to service design.

189
00:09:47.740 --> 00:09:51.360
Who then gets into the weeds of what's it
take to actually manufacture this thing,
