assimilate it into your person, and
then be ready for the next thing.

522
00:28:13.040 --> 00:28:15.646
We don't wanna open
the flood gates as it were.

523
00:28:15.646 --> 00:28:16.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> So Terry, we look forward to

524
00:28:16.750 --> 00:28:18.210
seeing you in the upcoming episodes.

525
00:28:18.210 --> 00:28:20.710
We look forward to seeing our
lovely audience out there as well.

526
00:28:20.710 --> 00:28:22.300
As for this one,
it's time for us to sign off.

527
00:28:22.300 --> 00:28:24.530
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

528
00:28:24.530 --> 00:28:25.700
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

529
00:28:25.700 --> 00:28:27.881
>> See you next time.

530
00:28:27.881 --> 00:28:33.795
[MUSIC]

531
00:28:33.795 --> 00:28:37.040
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry discuss Capacity Management which helps you understand, analyze, and discuss how to increase quality assurance for introducing and modifying services that are fit-for-purpose and/or fit-for-use.
episodes.title: Capacity Management Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.154
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.154 --> 00:00:05.965
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.965 --> 00:00:08.081
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.081 --> 00:00:11.971
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.971 --> 00:00:14.214
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:14.214 --> 00:00:17.669
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.669 --> 00:00:19.593
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

8
00:00:19.593 --> 00:00:24.172
in today's episode well we are coming
back with more on our ITEL PPO series.

9
00:00:24.172 --> 00:00:29.894
And joining us in the studio yet again,
continuing our conversation on capacity.

10
00:00:29.894 --> 00:00:32.589
That's right, I wanted to make
sure I was on the right show here,

11
00:00:32.589 --> 00:00:35.484
[LAUGH] capacity management,
is our good friend Mister Terry Decker.

12
00:00:35.484 --> 00:00:36.981
Terry we are glad to have you again, man.

13
00:00:36.981 --> 00:00:37.669
How's it going today?

14
00:00:37.669 --> 00:00:40.356
>> Going great,
happy to be here as always.

15
00:00:40.356 --> 00:00:44.311
And as Daniel said, we're continuing
our discussion of capacity management,

16
00:00:44.311 --> 00:00:48.208
one of the four service design processes
there in scope of planning protects and

17
00:00:48.208 --> 00:00:49.270
optimization.

18
00:00:49.270 --> 00:00:52.714
We also got demand management
to cover off another episode.

19
00:00:52.714 --> 00:00:56.490
So capacity management,
you may recall is got three parts to it.

20
00:00:56.490 --> 00:00:59.985
It's got component capacity,
service capacity, and business capacity.

21
00:00:59.985 --> 00:01:02.204
We had a good discussion
about business capacity.

22
00:01:02.204 --> 00:01:04.150
We're going to take up service and
component capacity next.

23
00:01:04.150 --> 00:01:06.879
So here's service capacity,
this concept is simple.

24
00:01:06.879 --> 00:01:09.288
It's a pretty picture,
the concept is simple.

25
00:01:09.288 --> 00:01:14.411
As time goes forward, capacity can change,
or capacity needs can change.

26
00:01:14.411 --> 00:01:18.300
So understanding the trending over time is
an aspect of capacity management planning

27
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:19.658
that needs to be put in place.

28
00:01:19.658 --> 00:01:22.695
So while you're designed
capacity into your service,

29
00:01:22.695 --> 00:01:27.150
you need to manage it over time as well,
after the service is operational.

30
00:01:27.150 --> 00:01:29.750
You see the acronyms here or
the abbreviations,

31
00:01:29.750 --> 00:01:32.440
Service Level Requirement and
Service Level Agreements.

32
00:01:32.440 --> 00:01:35.875
Service level requirements
feed service level agreements.

33
00:01:35.875 --> 00:01:40.401
They're high level understanding of
what the service needs to deliver,

34
00:01:40.401 --> 00:01:42.738
how often they need to be there, etc.

35
00:01:42.738 --> 00:01:46.243
The example I've mentioned
in other episodes about

36
00:01:46.243 --> 00:01:50.785
trying to anticipate the demand for
learning management service,

37
00:01:50.785 --> 00:01:56.370
converting PowerPoint presentations to
e-learning as part of an IT service.

38
00:01:56.370 --> 00:02:01.160
Well the service level requirements,
scoping those out, could lead to a service

39
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:04.430
level agreement that gets very
specific and very measurable.

40
00:02:04.430 --> 00:02:08.500
And when we in real life when we
rolled out that particular service,

41
00:02:08.500 --> 00:02:11.070
the demand was considerably high.

42
00:02:11.070 --> 00:02:16.258
So we had maybe five people on our
team that were doing that every day,

43
00:02:16.258 --> 00:02:22.089
seven hours a day, and just churning
out PowerPoint conversions every day.

44
00:02:22.089 --> 00:02:25.035
And then as we begin to
satisfy the pent up demand,

45
00:02:25.035 --> 00:02:30.020
because of all the existing PowerPoints,
it began to taper off a little bit.

46
00:02:30.020 --> 00:02:33.415
Now, this particular example shows
a trend going upward, right?

47
00:02:33.415 --> 00:02:37.103
Well the trend can also go downward,
where you end up with less demand.

48
00:02:37.103 --> 00:02:38.788
Understanding trends therefore,

49
00:02:38.788 --> 00:02:41.882
is an aspect of capacity management
that needs to be put in place.

50
00:02:41.882 --> 00:02:45.670
So you can see whether it's going up or
whether it's going down and

51
00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:48.410
try to anticipate just what that means.

52
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:49.510
Certainly you don't want to overbuild.

53
00:02:49.510 --> 00:02:52.560
You don't want to have five people
twiddling their thumbs in the conversion

54
00:02:52.560 --> 00:02:53.370
process.

55
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:56.959
You also don't want to have five people
not meeting the agreed targets of churning

56
00:02:56.959 --> 00:02:59.417
those things because there's so
much demand, right?

57
00:02:59.417 --> 00:03:03.666
So you have to have the right
size of service capacity to be

58
00:03:03.666 --> 00:03:08.104
able to be ongoing successful
on behalf of your customers.

59
00:03:08.104 --> 00:03:11.961
At some point it could trend downward,
at some point it could trend upward.

60
00:03:11.961 --> 00:03:14.879
Understanding the trends
is going to be key.

61
00:03:14.879 --> 00:03:17.510
Service management is related to that.

62
00:03:17.510 --> 00:03:20.110
Of course, component capacity management.

63
00:03:20.110 --> 00:03:22.890
Here we're dealing with just software,
disks,

64
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:27.940
network bandwidth, network connections,
license capacity, all right?

65
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:31.040
Those things that are related
directly to technology.

66
00:03:32.130 --> 00:03:35.115
Trying to be predictive and
proactive is the best way forward.

67
00:03:35.115 --> 00:03:38.632
But you also have the reactive piece,
as we talked about in earlier episodes.

68
00:03:38.632 --> 00:03:42.798
Being able to respond to the trends
related to component capacity,

69
00:03:42.798 --> 00:03:46.095
getting in front of the fact
the disk is getting full.

70
00:03:46.095 --> 00:03:49.852
Clearing out log files or
adding additional storage, as an example.

71
00:03:49.852 --> 00:03:54.261
Or planning a server upgrade
a couple of weekends from now,

72
00:03:54.261 --> 00:03:58.336
because you realize
the server's getting taxed out.

73
00:03:58.336 --> 00:04:01.520
Going trending upward, cuz it's not gonna
be able to keep up with that next 2,000

74
00:04:01.520 --> 00:04:05.180
users that's gonna join in the couple
weeks or that sort of thing.

75
00:04:05.180 --> 00:04:07.590
So again, trend analysis,
understanding demand,

76
00:04:07.590 --> 00:04:11.850
and being able to be
predictive is one thing.

77
00:04:11.850 --> 00:04:15.859
But also monitoring as it goes along so
you can be reactive, okay.

78
00:04:15.859 --> 00:04:20.569
It's kinda interesting that monitoring
is certainly a reactive activity.

79
00:04:20.569 --> 00:04:23.366
You're responding to
something you've seen.

80
00:04:23.366 --> 00:04:26.770
But if you're good at it,
it's almost as good as proactive.

81
00:04:26.770 --> 00:04:31.011
Cuz you're getting in front of the failure
or running out of disk space, or

82
00:04:31.011 --> 00:04:35.064
running out of processor speed,
etc., or running out of bandwidth.

83
00:04:35.064 --> 00:04:36.089
All right, so

84
00:04:36.089 --> 00:04:41.482
what types of things might you be
considering under Capacity Management?

85
00:04:41.482 --> 00:04:46.219
New technology exploitation, we had
a brief discussion earlier about having

86
00:04:46.219 --> 00:04:51.042
elastic capacity, like you can get from
cloud computing or hosted solutions.

87
00:04:51.042 --> 00:04:55.048
I cited the Commonwealth of Virginia
using an elastic approach with a cloud

88
00:04:55.048 --> 00:04:58.930
computing organization so
that they can manage your elections.

89
00:04:58.930 --> 00:05:01.488
It gets really busy in October and
November, not so

90
00:05:01.488 --> 00:05:03.758
busy during the rest of
the times of the year.

91
00:05:03.758 --> 00:05:07.719
So be able to expand outward and
capture that heavy-duty time and

92
00:05:07.719 --> 00:05:09.888
then go back down to normal sizing.

93
00:05:09.888 --> 00:05:12.940
So that's exploiting new technology,
right?

94
00:05:12.940 --> 00:05:15.609
Virtualization has been another
technology exploited for the, for

95
00:05:15.609 --> 00:05:16.489
the sake of capacity.

96
00:05:16.489 --> 00:05:19.445
Being able to easily capture
an image on one server and

97
00:05:19.445 --> 00:05:21.809
put it on a more powerful server later,
and

98
00:05:21.809 --> 00:05:25.730
pick up where you left off the next day,
right, that sort of thing.

99
00:05:25.730 --> 00:05:30.284
So being able to reuse architectures
can also help with capacity management.

100
00:05:30.284 --> 00:05:34.720
Virtualization is a key way to manage
those different architectures.

101
00:05:34.720 --> 00:05:36.566
So it's pretty clever.

102
00:05:36.566 --> 00:05:39.400
Also understanding relationships
to demand management.

103
00:05:39.400 --> 00:05:42.590
We'll talk about demand
management in detail later on.

104
00:05:42.590 --> 00:05:43.700
But in a nutshell,

105
00:05:43.700 --> 00:05:47.755
what demand management is doing is try to
anticipate what the demand's gonna be.

106
00:05:47.755 --> 00:05:50.305
We anticipate 5,000 users.

107
00:05:50.305 --> 00:05:54.855
We anticipate 500 PowerPoints a month for
the next six months,

108
00:05:54.855 --> 00:05:58.065
tapering off to 200 a month
by the end of the year.

109
00:05:58.065 --> 00:06:02.682
Demand management is asking questions in a
predictive sense, at the strategic level,

110
00:06:02.682 --> 00:06:07.192
at the service strategy level,
to make sure that you're funding the right

111
00:06:07.192 --> 00:06:09.872
services, the right capacity for
the right services.

112
00:06:09.872 --> 00:06:13.212
Again, had we done it better in the
example I gave you, we wouldn't have been

113
00:06:13.212 --> 00:06:18.862
surprised by the unspent demand or the
unmet demand of converting PowerPoints.

114
00:06:18.862 --> 00:06:21.829
Had we asked good questions about hey,
how many PowerPoints do you have?

115
00:06:21.829 --> 00:06:23.570
Do you wanna convert those?

116
00:06:23.570 --> 00:06:27.693
Had we asked those questions through a
demand management regiment, we'd have been

117
00:06:27.693 --> 00:06:31.830
better prepared to manage the capacity
answer to that demand management question.

118
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:35.383
And of course, coming up with
appropriate modelling and trending so

119
00:06:35.383 --> 00:06:38.209
that you don't have to
reinvent the wheel every time.

120
00:06:38.209 --> 00:06:41.505
If you know you need
to serve 50,000 users,

121
00:06:41.505 --> 00:06:45.754
that's a different question
than managing 5,000 users.

122
00:06:45.754 --> 00:06:46.860
Are they heavy hitting?

123
00:06:46.860 --> 00:06:48.678
What type of activities are they
doing when they get there?

124
00:06:48.678 --> 00:06:50.571
Are they submitting big queries or

125
00:06:50.571 --> 00:06:53.451
are they just kind of
transactional kind of things?

126
00:06:53.451 --> 00:06:56.620
Hit and go away, right,
understanding those kinds of activities.

127
00:06:56.620 --> 00:07:00.825
So modeling and trending, coming up with
ways that you can repeat that modeling and

128
00:07:00.825 --> 00:07:02.809
trending through capacity planning,

129
00:07:02.809 --> 00:07:06.918
can help streamline the capacity planning
process and the activities therein.

130
00:07:06.918 --> 00:07:10.923
And of course, application sizing
related to those modeling and trending.

131
00:07:10.923 --> 00:07:12.818
Just how big does
the application have to be?

132
00:07:12.818 --> 00:07:14.590
How many users is it going to support?

133
00:07:14.590 --> 00:07:20.447
When, how heavy hitting are those users,
etc.?

134
00:07:20.447 --> 00:07:22.775
So certainly related to design,

135
00:07:22.775 --> 00:07:27.941
we talk about service design being
the stage where you try to anticipate.

136
00:07:27.941 --> 00:07:30.652
Well, understanding the new
technologies that we just talked about,

137
00:07:30.652 --> 00:07:31.655
can help play into there.

138
00:07:31.655 --> 00:07:33.222
Design resilience,

139
00:07:33.222 --> 00:07:38.800
coming up with ways to improve
availability through capacity management.

140
00:07:38.800 --> 00:07:43.063
Component failure impact analysis,
when do services fail?

141
00:07:43.063 --> 00:07:47.687
We'll talk about that in detail when
we talk about availability management.

142
00:07:47.687 --> 00:07:51.757
Basically, what you're trying to do is
making sure you're building it with

143
00:07:51.757 --> 00:07:52.893
resilience in mind.

144
00:07:52.893 --> 00:07:57.260
Nothing really new conceptually there,
okay?

145
00:07:57.260 --> 00:07:58.421
So let's look at these.

146
00:07:58.421 --> 00:08:01.971
And keep in mind that this is probably
a good point of memorization,

147
00:08:01.971 --> 00:08:04.290
because they could simply use these words.

148
00:08:04.290 --> 00:08:08.580
On an exam, so exam takers, take heed,
there may be a choice, for instance,

149
00:08:08.580 --> 00:08:12.935
related to a capacity management question
where they're clearly asking about

150
00:08:12.935 --> 00:08:17.880
capacity management, and you need to
come up with the appropriate activities.

151
00:08:17.880 --> 00:08:22.310
Notice the activities here of tuning,
implementation, monitoring and

152
00:08:22.310 --> 00:08:26.010
analysis and
notice that it's cyclical, right?

153
00:08:26.010 --> 00:08:27.460
That's at the top of this graphic.

154
00:08:27.460 --> 00:08:33.385
Let me get my laser pointer here and
reinforce those.

155
00:08:33.385 --> 00:08:36.075
So it's, again,
it's kinda worth committing to memory

156
00:08:36.075 --> 00:08:39.525
these activities because maybe
what the test maker might do is,

157
00:08:39.525 --> 00:08:44.455
within the answer to the question,
include activities of capacity management.

158
00:08:44.455 --> 00:08:45.825
Cuz you're trying to convince the CIO,

159
00:08:45.825 --> 00:08:48.360
what are you gonna be doing
in capacity management?

160
00:08:48.360 --> 00:08:50.360
Well what activities would you be doing?

161
00:08:50.360 --> 00:08:52.390
These are the four activities, right?

162
00:08:52.390 --> 00:08:55.920
So tuning, implementation,
monitoring and analysis.

163
00:08:55.920 --> 00:08:59.860
We've talked about these, but not in
those necessarily specific terms, right?

164
00:08:59.860 --> 00:09:04.640
Notice that what you have underneath it is
different models or definitions of things.

165
00:09:04.640 --> 00:09:08.160
You got a resource thresholds,
service thresholds.

166
00:09:08.160 --> 00:09:11.910
These kind of look like databases,
a big database.

167
00:09:11.910 --> 00:09:14.970
In fact, that's what this biggest
cylinder is trying to show,

168
00:09:14.970 --> 00:09:17.480
Capacity Management Information System.

169
00:09:17.480 --> 00:09:20.670
So one of the outputs of capacity
management is a capacity plan,

170
00:09:20.670 --> 00:09:23.530
right, you'll certainly have those.

171
00:09:23.530 --> 00:09:27.880
Also keeping up with the relevant data
related to capacity management planning

172
00:09:27.880 --> 00:09:30.310
is a goal of capacity management.

173
00:09:30.310 --> 00:09:32.850
And ITIL simply gives
that set of data a name,

174
00:09:32.850 --> 00:09:35.660
the capacity management
information system.

175
00:09:35.660 --> 00:09:38.620
Availability has one, called availability
management information system.

176
00:09:38.620 --> 00:09:40.940
Continuity has one, security has one,

177
00:09:40.940 --> 00:09:46.020
its own set of data that helps inform
the process of capacity management.

178
00:09:46.020 --> 00:09:48.534
Keeping up with the data points, okay.

179
00:09:48.534 --> 00:09:52.240
All right, so what are these activities?

180
00:09:52.240 --> 00:09:54.880
Monitoring, we've talked about those,

181
00:09:54.880 --> 00:09:59.085
monitoring the utilization
of the resources.

182
00:09:59.085 --> 00:10:03.810
Response time,
how quickly are you responding to things?

183
00:10:03.810 --> 00:10:05.270
For instance, if they say,

184
00:10:07.160 --> 00:10:12.150
you're able to manage 500 requests
a month for e-learning conversions for

185
00:10:12.150 --> 00:10:14.740
those learning management services,
is that good or is that bad?

186
00:10:14.740 --> 00:10:17.410
So response time,
how quickly are you turning those around?

187
00:10:17.410 --> 00:10:21.760
It's not just 500 a month,
it's you turn them around in 24 hours or

188
00:10:21.760 --> 00:10:23.260
48 hours, that type of thing.

189
00:10:24.702 --> 00:10:28.980
So we're talking about how you're
utilizing that service as well as

190
00:10:28.980 --> 00:10:30.940
how quickly that service
is turning things around.

191
00:10:32.680 --> 00:10:35.650
Doing your analysis,
what are the patterns of the service?

192
00:10:35.650 --> 00:10:39.020
Does it tend to be heavier
on Wednesdays than Fridays?

193
00:10:39.020 --> 00:10:42.670
Does it tend to be heavier in
the afternoon than in the morning,

194
00:10:42.670 --> 00:10:43.570
those types of things.

195
00:10:43.570 --> 00:10:47.510
Understanding those patterns
can help you better model for

196
00:10:47.510 --> 00:10:49.860
the future as well to
establish your trends.

197
00:10:51.810 --> 00:10:54.900
And then tuning is adjusting, right?

198
00:10:54.900 --> 00:10:58.200
It's making your adjustments and
perhaps even influencing demand.

199
00:10:58.200 --> 00:11:02.470
Moving activities to the morning
instead of the afternoon,

200
00:11:02.470 --> 00:11:05.914
if you can influence
the right behaviors there.

201
00:11:05.914 --> 00:11:11.036
As it relates to component planning,
maybe it's reusing capacity on the network

202
00:11:11.036 --> 00:11:15.950
differently, doing some quality of
service analysis and that sort of thing.

203
00:11:15.950 --> 00:11:21.127
We once had a situation where the sales
teams in the far east, they had critical

204
00:11:21.127 --> 00:11:26.636
training periods where they came into the
office instead of being out in the field.

205
00:11:26.636 --> 00:11:29.122
They came into the office quarterly, and

206
00:11:29.122 --> 00:11:32.400
used the learning management
service quite heavily.

207
00:11:32.400 --> 00:11:35.750
And it happened to be one
of the weaker points we had

208
00:11:35.750 --> 00:11:40.660
on our wide area network was that
space over there in the far east.

209
00:11:40.660 --> 00:11:42.620
We had some slow links over there.

210
00:11:42.620 --> 00:11:44.380
So architecturally speaking,

211
00:11:44.380 --> 00:11:46.370
we needed to manage that demand
a little bit differently.

212
00:11:46.370 --> 00:11:51.811
So instead of sending them across
the WAN link to stream their e-learning,

213
00:11:51.811 --> 00:11:56.319
we redesigned the technology in
such a way that it downloaded to

214
00:11:56.319 --> 00:11:57.947
a local server first.

215
00:11:57.947 --> 00:12:01.276
And they could stream it on that side of
the WAN instead of going through the wide

216
00:12:01.276 --> 00:12:02.490
area network.

217
00:12:02.490 --> 00:12:04.840
That's the nature of capacity planning.

218
00:12:04.840 --> 00:12:07.420
We knew we had a bunch of people who were
gonna demand it at certain times of the

219
00:12:07.420 --> 00:12:11.490
month, we could turn the switch basically
and manage that traffic as we needed to.

if you get in front of it,

00:37:39.400 --> 00:37:44.440
you won't have reputation loss or
upset customers, or

688
00:37:44.440 --> 00:37:47.880
a delay in delivering the value your
service was intended to deliver.

689
00:37:49.620 --> 00:37:50.990
You get too bureaucratic.

690
00:37:52.180 --> 00:37:55.800
Data overload, which is also one of
the challenges, they kind of go together.

691
00:37:55.800 --> 00:37:56.967
All right.

692
00:37:58.997 --> 00:38:01.180
Roles and responsibilities.

693
00:38:01.180 --> 00:38:02.910
Pretty short list here.

694
00:38:02.910 --> 00:38:05.500
I mean, pretty long list, but
it all boils down to this.

695
00:38:05.500 --> 00:38:08.180
Make sure you have someone that owns this.

696
00:38:08.180 --> 00:38:13.840
Someone owns the process and a wise person
manages the process, or wise people.

697
00:38:13.840 --> 00:38:17.990
And make sure you have often and
early engagement with the business so

698
00:38:17.990 --> 00:38:22.850
that you can keep up on the business
capacity side as much as the component and

699
00:38:22.850 --> 00:38:23.610
service capacity.

700
00:38:24.720 --> 00:38:27.390
So come up with these activities
as you play them out.

701
00:38:27.390 --> 00:38:29.070
We've talked about each one of these.

702
00:38:29.070 --> 00:38:30.910
Report the incidents.

703
00:38:30.910 --> 00:38:34.370
Categorize them appropriately,
as a capacity issue, a performance issue,

704
00:38:34.370 --> 00:38:39.690
as opposed to some other topic, so
you can do your problem management

705
00:38:39.690 --> 00:38:45.195
trend analysis and, therefore, root out
the underlying causes of your failures.

706
00:38:45.195 --> 00:38:47.535
As we talk about availability
a little bit later on,

707
00:38:47.535 --> 00:38:51.355
we'll look at some measurements in place
that could point to capacity issues and

708
00:38:51.355 --> 00:38:55.345
vice versa, how capacity issues
could point to availability issues.

709
00:38:55.345 --> 00:38:56.945
We'll try to connect
the dots there as well.

710
00:38:58.945 --> 00:39:02.474
And be often and early with your
reporting against capacity.

711
00:39:02.474 --> 00:39:06.701
Produce regular management reports,
being transparent about how good you are,

712
00:39:06.701 --> 00:39:08.609
or how good you ain't, so to speak.

713
00:39:08.609 --> 00:39:11.034
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

714
00:39:11.034 --> 00:39:15.240
that completes the lecture
part of capacity management.

715
00:39:15.240 --> 00:39:16.630
I invite you to some self study.

716
00:39:16.630 --> 00:39:20.430
There's an exercise in the downloads
that's related to this.

717
00:39:21.480 --> 00:39:24.439
This one walks you through,
suggesting about 45 minutes.

718
00:39:25.490 --> 00:39:27.120
And then, there's this one called,

719
00:39:27.120 --> 00:39:30.610
Capacity Management activity,
that suggests about 20 minutes.

720
00:39:30.610 --> 00:39:31.520
Again, available for

721
00:39:31.520 --> 00:39:37.320
download in the show files up above
me here of the first episode.

722
00:39:37.320 --> 00:39:38.980
And it's a zip file.

723
00:39:38.980 --> 00:39:45.920
Unzip that and you'll find this this
activity, exercise, there, yep.

724
00:39:45.920 --> 00:39:50.584
>> All right Terry, capacity management
is definitely a bit of, well,

725
00:39:50.584 --> 00:39:52.578
it's not very complicated.

726
00:39:52.578 --> 00:39:55.500
I think anybody's that is watching this
would understand what you are saying,

727
00:39:55.500 --> 00:39:56.920
all of the concepts make sense.

728
00:39:56.920 --> 00:39:59.630
But it is very nuanced, and
that is where we have to pay attention.

729
00:39:59.630 --> 00:40:02.507
We have to make sure that we understand
the minutia and all the little bells and

730
00:40:02.507 --> 00:40:04.099
whistles that they throw on top of this,
so

731
00:40:04.099 --> 00:40:06.509
that we know everything that
goes within capacity management.

732
00:40:06.509 --> 00:40:10.002
Might take you a little bit so that you
know you understand each and every one of

733
00:40:10.002 --> 00:40:13.355
them and know which one of those are,
as far as capacity management goes.

734
00:40:13.355 --> 00:40:15.606
So make sure you really
pay attention to that,

735
00:40:15.606 --> 00:40:19.358
since you have that grasp by the time
you enter any testing booth, as it were,

736
00:40:19.358 --> 00:40:21.630
so that you don't get
those questions wrong.

737
00:40:21.630 --> 00:40:25.330
I wanna make sure you get the fives, and
not the threes, or the ones or the zeros,

738
00:40:25.330 --> 00:40:25.993
definitely.

739
00:40:25.993 --> 00:40:27.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That being said we have blown

740
00:40:27.480 --> 00:40:30.550
time for this episode, so
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

741
00:40:30.550 --> 00:40:32.150
We do thank you, Terry, for joining us.

742
00:40:32.150 --> 00:40:34.090
>> Glad to be here.
>> And lending your expertise.

743
00:40:34.090 --> 00:40:36.600
We do thank you for watching,
but signing off for

744
00:40:36.600 --> 00:40:38.910
IT ProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

745
00:40:38.910 --> 00:40:39.870
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

746
00:40:39.870 --> 00:40:42.003
>> We'll see you next time.

747
00:40:42.003 --> 00:40:48.079
[MUSIC]

748
00:40:48.079 --> 00:40:50.949
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry explore Availability Management. Here they take the time to help you understand, analyze, and discuss how Availability Management should be conducted to contribute to quality assurance for introducing services that are fit-for-purpose and fit-for-use.
episodes.title: Availability Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.431
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm you host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.431 --> 00:00:11.366
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.366 --> 00:00:13.788
>> All right, greetings everyone and

4
00:00:13.788 --> 00:00:16.970
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.970 --> 00:00:21.434
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we are hitting you today with more

6
00:00:21.434 --> 00:00:23.174
on our ITIL PPO, that's right.

7
00:00:23.174 --> 00:00:27.930
And joining us back in the studio again
today, our good friend Mr. Terry Decker.

8
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:29.380
Terry, welcome back man,
how's it going today?

9
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:30.980
>> It's going great, happy to be here.

10
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:35.160
We got some good topic here,
availability management.

11
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:39.180
A very important topic, maybe the gold
standard of the warranty processes.

12
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:42.390
We have capacity management,
and previous episodes.

13
00:00:42.390 --> 00:00:45.310
Now focusing on availability management,
and obviously they're related.

14
00:00:45.310 --> 00:00:48.860
If you don't have sufficient capacity,
things can fall over, and

15
00:00:48.860 --> 00:00:49.980
therefore be unavailable.

16
00:00:49.980 --> 00:00:53.270
So, these don't operate in a vacuum,
or an island all by themselves.

17
00:00:53.270 --> 00:00:56.360
So, keep that in mind as
we learn these things.

18
00:00:56.360 --> 00:00:58.320
Okay, so
as we look at the slide deck here,

19
00:00:58.320 --> 00:01:01.750
and look at some of the objectives
of availability management.

20
00:01:01.750 --> 00:01:05.990
As you can see I annotated he's as
proactive and reactive as we go through

21
00:01:05.990 --> 00:01:08.370
these, and I'm gonna go ahead and
belabor these for a little bit.

22
00:01:08.370 --> 00:01:10.790
Produce and maintain an availability plan.

23
00:01:10.790 --> 00:01:15.960
This is done at the service design level,
and it is intended to be proactive.

24
00:01:15.960 --> 00:01:17.320
You're coming up with a plan for

25
00:01:17.320 --> 00:01:21.890
how you're going to ensure availability
of performance is going to be met, right?

26
00:01:21.890 --> 00:01:22.960
So you have an SLA,

27
00:01:22.960 --> 00:01:27.460
you have a general understanding of
when the users are gonna be there.

28
00:01:27.460 --> 00:01:32.231
Is it need to be available Monday through
Friday, nine to five, is it 24/7,

29
00:01:32.231 --> 00:01:37.550
is it 99.9% availability acceptable,
is 98% availability acceptable?

30
00:01:37.550 --> 00:01:40.330
But you have those general
requirements in play, and

31
00:01:40.330 --> 00:01:43.970
you proactively plan to meet
those requirements, right?

32
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:46.330
Provide guidance and
advice on availability issues.

33
00:01:46.330 --> 00:01:47.990
This is more reactive.

34
00:01:47.990 --> 00:01:51.950
If you have ongoing failures,
you're providing guidance and

35
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:53.420
advice on how to fix them.

36
00:01:53.420 --> 00:01:56.110
So that's kind of the reactive part of it,
right?

37
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:59.830
Manage service and resource availability
performance and improvement.

38
00:01:59.830 --> 00:02:03.640
Well, this is kind of operational,
it's reactive, but

39
00:02:03.640 --> 00:02:08.450
also has a significant proactive aspect
to it in that this idea of improvement is

40
00:02:08.450 --> 00:02:12.150
you're looking at the landscape
across perhaps multiple services and

41
00:02:12.150 --> 00:02:15.170
saying just how good you are at
this availability thing.

42
00:02:15.170 --> 00:02:17.630
Do you have lots of services
falling over often?

43
00:02:17.630 --> 00:02:21.050
Do you have just a few
services falling over often?

44
00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:24.350
Do you have one service that
doesn't fail very often, but

45
00:02:24.350 --> 00:02:26.100
when it does it goes down for days?

46
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:26.730
That kinda thing.

47
00:02:26.730 --> 00:02:30.750
So understanding the nuances of
your availability management

48
00:02:30.750 --> 00:02:33.720
regime is a proactive nature as well.

49
00:02:33.720 --> 00:02:37.573
Assist with availability related incidents
and problem of course that's reactive.

50
00:02:37.573 --> 00:02:42.171
If something falls over you need to do the
root cause analysis of why it fell over

51
00:02:42.171 --> 00:02:45.360
and root out that problem and
eliminate it.

52
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:48.370
But that has obviously reactive
because you have issues.

53
00:02:48.370 --> 00:02:49.198
Things have fallen over.

54
00:02:49.198 --> 00:02:54.460
And then assess impact and
change requests on availability.

55
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:56.370
This is proactive, as well.

56
00:02:56.370 --> 00:02:58.474
Through the change management process,

57
00:02:58.474 --> 00:03:01.426
you might discern that
you're adding 5,000 users.

58
00:03:01.426 --> 00:03:03.620
Is that gonna affect availability?

59
00:03:03.620 --> 00:03:09.030
Could that tip the capacity scale
beyond tolerance levels and

60
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:10.290
cause your services to fail?

61
00:03:10.290 --> 00:03:15.680
Or you evaluate a change request and
realize you're adding some architectural

62
00:03:15.680 --> 00:03:22.015
components, such as a video
provisioning system, that sorta thing.

63
00:03:22.015 --> 00:03:25.975
So, capacity, again, is gonna be assessing
whether or not you have the appropriate

64
00:03:25.975 --> 00:03:28.875
component capacity for this, but
it also affects availability.

65
00:03:28.875 --> 00:03:32.425
So, again, you, kinda,
see the connections between them, okay?

66
00:03:32.425 --> 00:03:35.635
So, we'll be reinforcing these
reactive-proactives as we go through

67
00:03:35.635 --> 00:03:41.060
several of the slides in this deck, okay.

68
00:03:41.060 --> 00:03:44.710
Availability management is alive and
well in service design.

69
00:03:44.710 --> 00:03:47.340
And it's also involved in implementation.

70
00:03:47.340 --> 00:03:49.790
So when it goes through transition,

71
00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:54.120
availability management's there to make
sure that everything's set up right or

72
00:03:54.120 --> 00:03:56.600
that all the measurements are in place or
going to be in place.

73
00:03:57.750 --> 00:04:01.770
And therefore making sure that you can
have ongoing improvement later on.

74
00:04:01.770 --> 00:04:05.130
Right, so it's alive and
well in service design.

75
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:08.270
It's there through transition,
availability management is to make sure

76
00:04:08.270 --> 00:04:10.830
that the appropriate
measures are brought in.

77
00:04:10.830 --> 00:04:13.770
And of course,
it's there in operations to actually see

78
00:04:13.770 --> 00:04:16.720
the effects of the availability plan
to see that it's working, okay.

79
00:04:18.218 --> 00:04:23.110
All operational services.

80
00:04:23.110 --> 00:04:28.170
So everything that you care to operate
in your environment as a service is

81
00:04:28.170 --> 00:04:30.850
within scope of availability management.

82
00:04:30.850 --> 00:04:35.720
New services, existing services that
already have agreements underneath them,

83
00:04:35.720 --> 00:04:38.150
service level agreements and
service level requirements.

84
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:41.750
And all IT services and
components that may impact availability.

85
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:45.610
So, it's not just the application at
the top, it's all the servers and

86
00:04:45.610 --> 00:04:48.760
all the databases, the network,
everything underneath it as well.

87
00:04:48.760 --> 00:04:52.550
So supporting services as well as
customer facing services are in play.

88
00:04:53.729 --> 00:04:55.008
All right?

89
00:04:56.726 --> 00:04:57.640
Why?

90
00:04:57.640 --> 00:04:58.550
Why would you do this?

91
00:04:58.550 --> 00:04:59.910
>> The immortal question.

92
00:04:59.910 --> 00:05:00.630
>> Yeah, that's right.

93
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:02.290
The immortal question.

94
00:05:02.290 --> 00:05:02.810
>> Why?
>> Right, so

95
00:05:02.810 --> 00:05:07.820
why, what value does availability
management bring to the business?

96
00:05:07.820 --> 00:05:11.020
It's actually probably the gold
standard when it comes to

97
00:05:11.020 --> 00:05:12.390
what customers care about.

98
00:05:12.390 --> 00:05:14.410
Of course they want it to
have functionality but

99
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:20.150
if it's not there when they expect it to
be there your reputation is tarnished.

100
00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:23.440
And I appreciate the upper case there.

101
00:05:23.440 --> 00:05:24.730
Customer loyalty is over.

102
00:05:24.730 --> 00:05:26.540
You can't expect a loyal customer.

103
00:05:26.540 --> 00:05:28.970
You're just trying to retain
them cause if it fails,

104
00:05:28.970 --> 00:05:31.740
you'll go somewhere else if you can,
right.

105
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:32.850
That sort of thing.

106
00:05:32.850 --> 00:05:33.760
So it is,

107
00:05:33.760 --> 00:05:37.820
if it's not availability when people, when
your customers think it should be, you're

108
00:05:37.820 --> 00:05:42.110
going to lose potentially your reputation,
but you're also going to lose customers.

109
00:05:42.110 --> 00:05:42.930
Not a good prospect.

110
00:05:48.072 --> 00:05:51.629
Some guiding principles related to
availability management, again,

111
00:05:51.629 --> 00:05:55.711
kinda riding the same horse we're seeing
before is that things are gonna go wrong,

112
00:05:55.711 --> 00:05:58.000
availability is not a perfect science.

113
00:05:58.000 --> 00:05:59.026
Things will fall over.

114
00:05:59.026 --> 00:06:04.180
IT deals with complex
configuration of systems and

115
00:06:04.180 --> 00:06:08.790
services and
in that complexity things can go wrong.

116
00:06:08.790 --> 00:06:11.330
So failures are actually tolerant or

117
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:15.240
tolerable by many customers they
expect that it's not perfect.

118
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:16.940
But what's your response to it?

119
00:06:16.940 --> 00:06:18.850
Right?
How quickly can you recover?

120
00:06:18.850 --> 00:06:21.060
Right?
How often does that happen?

121
00:06:21.060 --> 00:06:23.700
Right?
Sure it's gonna happen every now and then.

122
00:06:23.700 --> 00:06:25.750
Keep that limited, right.

123
00:06:25.750 --> 00:06:30.060
Also, recognize that availability is only
as strong as the weakest link, right?

124
00:06:30.060 --> 00:06:32.980
If there is a single point of failure
somewhere in your infrastructure or

125
00:06:32.980 --> 00:06:37.620
your architecture, if that fails,
the whole thing comes tumbling down.

126
00:06:37.620 --> 00:06:39.490
Obviously, availability could be affected.

127
00:06:39.490 --> 00:06:43.630
By the way, that single point of failure
and the analysis therein is very close to

128
00:06:43.630 --> 00:06:46.660
another process that we will be
discussing called continuity management.

129
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:49.390
Continuity management is trying to discern
those single points of failure and

130
00:06:49.390 --> 00:06:51.740
make sure that they are shored up, right.

131
00:06:51.740 --> 00:06:54.790
So continuity and
affordability, capacity and

132
00:06:54.790 --> 00:06:57.480
availability, interrelated processes,
okay.

133
00:06:58.900 --> 00:07:03.900
All right, service availability
versus component availability.

134
00:07:03.900 --> 00:07:06.920
Probably the best way
to teach this aspect.

135
00:07:06.920 --> 00:07:11.765
Is it possible for a component to fail and
the service still be available?

136
00:07:13.515 --> 00:07:15.175
>> I would assume so.

137
00:07:15.175 --> 00:07:15.845
>> Yeah.

138
00:07:15.845 --> 00:07:21.315
If you can imagine an architecture where
you have several servers in a cluster.

139
00:07:21.315 --> 00:07:24.150
And if one of them fails you still
have three more to go, right?

140
00:07:24.150 --> 00:07:25.870
Three more to keep the service available.

141
00:07:25.870 --> 00:07:28.120
Now, there is some impact to
that perhaps going around.

142
00:07:28.120 --> 00:07:29.230
Maybe performance slows down,

143
00:07:29.230 --> 00:07:33.010
maybe you can't quite handle as many
users, maybe, right, or maybe not.

144
00:07:33.010 --> 00:07:36.510
Maybe it's just that robust, so
if you lose something, what about disks?

145
00:07:36.510 --> 00:07:41.630
If you lose a disk, is there an array
to ray or in a storage array?

146
00:07:41.630 --> 00:07:44.510
You have the ability to
survive a disk failure, right?

147
00:07:44.510 --> 00:07:48.930
So, components can fail and
the service should still be available.

148
00:07:48.930 --> 00:07:53.202
When you also consider service
availability you're also considering

149
00:07:53.202 --> 00:07:56.269
things that are beyond
technical in some regards.

150
00:07:56.269 --> 00:08:01.176
Is the service available if there's
not a computer for somebody?

151
00:08:01.176 --> 00:08:01.712
Right.

152
00:08:01.712 --> 00:08:04.692
It is not that the computer is broken or
unavailable,

153
00:08:04.692 --> 00:08:07.750
it is just you didn't provision
the computer in time.

154
00:08:07.750 --> 00:08:12.630
So some things like that could also play
into the mix of service availability.

155
00:08:12.630 --> 00:08:13.260
Right.

156
00:08:13.260 --> 00:08:15.470
So understand the difference
between component availability and

157
00:08:15.470 --> 00:08:17.800
service availability is important but

158
00:08:17.800 --> 00:08:22.422
actually, just keep in mind that
availability is accountable for both.

159
00:08:22.422 --> 00:08:26.526
In the end service availability as
well as the minute detail of component

160
00:08:26.526 --> 00:08:27.880
availability as well.

161
00:08:31.767 --> 00:08:35.550
Some language has you know,
some language availability management.

162
00:08:35.550 --> 00:08:40.070
Availability itself is as you can see
there, availability of a service or

163
00:08:40.070 --> 00:08:42.870
component to perform as required, yup.

164
00:08:42.870 --> 00:08:47.840
And as a measurement what availability is,
is the percentage of time

165
00:08:47.840 --> 00:08:50.520
that you've promised to be up,
that you're actually up.

166
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:53.920
So let us do the math for a little bit.

167
00:08:53.920 --> 00:08:58.660
If you promise to be available
Monday through Friday, 9 to 5.

168
00:08:58.660 --> 00:09:01.720
That happens to be 40 hours
that you've promised to be up.

169
00:09:01.720 --> 00:09:05.940
If during that time frame, and during that
window you're supposed to be available,

170
00:09:05.940 --> 00:09:07.770
you had a four hour outage that week.

171
00:09:07.770 --> 00:09:14.120
Four hours is one-tenth of 40,
so you had 10% of down time.

00:21:09.200 --> 00:21:11.260
So you're planning your outages.

413

It also gives you a point of reference for
communication to your customers.

414
00:21:16.980 --> 00:21:20.560
I mean, it's one thing to have
a regular schedule of maintenance.

415
00:21:20.560 --> 00:21:22.850
It's another thing to have
unplanned maintenance, right?

416
00:21:22.850 --> 00:21:26.678

to do because the vendor says if we don't

417
00:21:26.678 --> 00:21:28.660

418
00:21:28.660 --> 00:21:31.650
We're planning that for
Saturday, everyone.

419
00:21:31.650 --> 00:21:34.130
We have a projected service outage, a PSO.

420
00:21:34.130 --> 00:21:35.830
We have a document assist to everyone.

421
00:21:35.830 --> 00:21:37.980
Hey, we are down on Saturday,

422
00:21:37.980 --> 00:21:42.020

423
00:21:42.020 --> 00:21:46.940

people come to use the service that

424
00:21:46.940 --> 00:21:51.070

are immediately available to them there.

425
00:21:51.070 --> 00:21:52.039

426
00:21:52.039 --> 00:21:54.817
Availability management,
again is on point for

427
00:21:54.817 --> 00:21:57.469

428
00:21:59.059 --> 00:22:04.370
All right, now we look at the nuances
here of inputs triggers and outputs.

comeback for

more things to discuss here.

00:22:10.310 --> 00:22:12.400
>> Excellent stuff there,
we're reading stuff so far,

432
00:22:12.400 --> 00:22:14.190
hopefully you guys are getting

00:22:14.190 --> 00:22:14.870
I know I sure am.

It's a very interesting conversation

00:22:28.930 --> 00:22:33.720

440
00:22:33.720 --> 00:22:34.725
I like being proactive.

441
00:22:34.725 --> 00:22:35.499
>> Absolutely.

442
00:22:35.499 --> 00:22:37.030
That's my kind of tea right there.

00:22:40.580 --> 00:22:43.320

and taking things away,

45

So Security Management,
Continuity Management,

Access management, service level

problem management were also discussed

How it uses service level agreements to

00:02:31.880 --> 00:02:34.840
marching toward, right, or

That's closely related to

56

So we also talk about that

59

So that's a little spider web showing

60
00:02:56.045 --> 00:02:57.305
with each other, right?

61
00:02:58.315 --> 00:03:00.885

62
00:03:00.885 --> 00:03:05.732
Information management for
availability is all supposed to be

63
00:03:05.732 --> 00:03:09.150

management information system.

64
00:03:09.150 --> 00:03:10.040
We talked about this.

65

We talked about capacity management
in another episodes as well,

66
00:03:12.990 --> 00:03:18.530
where capacity management has a CMIS,
a capacity management information system.

67
00:03:18.530 --> 00:03:19.600
All the data points,

68
00:03:19.600 --> 00:03:24.430
all the information that help you manage
availability need to be collated.

This idea of a system doesn't mean
you're necessarily creating a great,

73
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:39.090
big super size system.

74
00:03:39.090 --> 00:03:43.870
It just means a lot of moving parts
moving together for a common purpose,

75
00:03:43.870 --> 00:03:46.596
this really is what
the information system here means.

76
00:03:46.596 --> 00:03:51.525
So if you formalize it into a group
of relational databases, if you

77
00:03:51.525 --> 00:03:56.360
organize into three or four spreadsheets
and six or seven documents, all

00:03:56.360 --> 00:03:59.440
that is gonna be part of your Availability
Management Information system.

00:03:59.440 --> 00:04:00.845

I've seen this played out

81
00:04:05.520 --> 00:04:09.130
It can be very effective for
you and simple and by that I mean,

82
00:04:09.130 --> 00:04:14.660
you have your modelling document,
your availability modelling ideas.

83
00:04:14.660 --> 00:04:17.480
You have your availability
management plans, right?

84
00:04:17.480 --> 00:04:19.820
And you have some location

00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:24.220
like a spreadsheet that can link out to
those different repositories as you need.

86
00:04:24.220 --> 00:04:27.300
And again,
it doesn't have to be an elaborately built

87
00:04:27.300 --> 00:04:29.600

88
00:04:29.600 --> 00:04:34.874
It's just a way to get all your
data in one stack, theoretically.

89
00:04:34.874 --> 00:04:36.980
Okay, alright.

90
00:04:36.980 --> 00:04:38.540
What's an availability management plan?

91
00:04:38.540 --> 00:04:40.960
Well it's answering all
the questions about availability.

92
00:04:40.960 --> 00:04:41.910
It really is.

93
00:04:41.910 --> 00:04:43.880
It's the plan of action, right?

94
00:04:43.880 --> 00:04:47.310
In the absence of one,
you're kinda guessing, right?

95
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:52.230
If it's informal, it's kinda okay but
what if you need to reference it later?

96
00:04:52.230 --> 00:04:54.880
The thing about an informal plan is that

97
00:04:54.880 --> 00:04:58.240
you won't necessarily get back to
it later on if you he just says,

98
00:04:58.240 --> 00:05:01.230
well you get to the meeting and
say let's do this and let's do that.

99
00:05:01.230 --> 00:05:02.710
That's a great idea.

100
00:05:02.710 --> 00:05:06.900
If you don't write it down, then later on
either the idea is lost or when you're

101
00:05:06.900 --> 00:05:10.720
doing some troubleshooting, you're not
really sure where you should turn.

102
00:05:10.720 --> 00:05:14.440
So if you've done a failure analysis,
a component failure impact analysis,

103
00:05:14.440 --> 00:05:18.949
or a service failure analysis as
one of your proactive activities.

104
00:05:18.949 --> 00:05:22.290
And you have identified your risk,
and have a risk register,

105
00:05:22.290 --> 00:05:24.490
that's all going to be made in
the availability management plan.

106
00:05:24.490 --> 00:05:28.100
Here's the things we've determined,
here's what we're going to do, and

107
00:05:28.100 --> 00:05:29.120
then you do it.

108
00:05:29.120 --> 00:05:31.280
So writing it down is important right?

109
00:05:33.510 --> 00:05:35.380
What are the key performance indicators?

110
00:05:35.380 --> 00:05:36.930
Really you're talking about measuring.

111
00:05:36.930 --> 00:05:41.680
What are the key metrics for availability?

112
00:05:41.680 --> 00:05:45.140
if you focus on the service, you're
looking at mean time between failures and

113
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:46.797
mean time to restore service, right?

114
00:05:49.090 --> 00:05:54.790
The MTBSI is Mean Time Between
Service Incidence, right?

115
00:05:54.790 --> 00:05:59.400
So MTBF, MTBSI, and
MTRS are subtle measurements related to

116
00:05:59.400 --> 00:06:02.320
the availability of your services, right?

117
00:06:04.040 --> 00:06:08.280
Review your SLAs and your other
agreements, and contracts to ensure that

118
00:06:08.280 --> 00:06:11.350
the targets are the same and
that you're meeting those targets, right?

119
00:06:11.350 --> 00:06:13.310
Those are some of
the service focus things.

120
00:06:13.310 --> 00:06:16.090
Access focus, are people able to access or

121
00:06:16.090 --> 00:06:18.340
is it available is what
we're talking about.

122
00:06:18.340 --> 00:06:20.800
Reduce the critical time failures, right?

123
00:06:20.800 --> 00:06:23.920
What I mean by that is, it's one thing,
maybe you're really good,

124
00:06:23.920 --> 00:06:27.560
your availability metrics are 99% and
you've only promised 98.

125
00:06:27.560 --> 00:06:32.280
But you had an outage
during the heaviest part of

126
00:06:32.280 --> 00:06:37.000
the sales season and lost 3 million
dollars, because the service was down.

127
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:37.880
Your metrics look good.

128
00:06:39.580 --> 00:06:43.232
But, my gosh, we had an outage at
that time which was very critical.

129
00:06:43.232 --> 00:06:47.240
So maybe one of the things you
measure is the critical time failures.

130
00:06:47.240 --> 00:06:48.860
When do services fail?

131
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:49.920
When is most critical.

132
00:06:49.920 --> 00:06:51.460
>> To start qualifying a little more.

133
00:06:51.460 --> 00:06:53.270
>> Yeah,
instead of having elastic measurement,

134
00:06:53.270 --> 00:06:55.880
we're 99% available what
are you complaining about?

135
00:06:55.880 --> 00:06:58.930
Well, you were down during the most
critical part of our business.

136
00:06:58.930 --> 00:06:59.930
That's worth it.

137
00:06:59.930 --> 00:07:04.500
So having nuance reports that can
show uptime during critical times

138
00:07:04.500 --> 00:07:08.470
as opposed to generic up time,
could be part of the way you do it.

139
00:07:08.470 --> 00:07:11.090
That's definitely business impact focused.

140
00:07:11.090 --> 00:07:13.130
It's focused on the customers, right?

141
00:07:13.130 --> 00:07:16.280
And I've seen exam questions
that tease out that nuance,

142
00:07:16.280 --> 00:07:20.340
where there'll clearly say,
we have great availability.

143
00:07:20.340 --> 00:07:21.320
What are you complaining about?

144
00:07:21.320 --> 00:07:24.130
We are meeting our expectations, right?

145
00:07:24.130 --> 00:07:26.810
It's in the SLA, it's over here, right?

146
00:07:26.810 --> 00:07:30.900
It just all points to the idea that
you can have nice and green metrics.

147
00:07:30.900 --> 00:07:34.910
The metrics look great, and
still have a dissatisfied customer, right?

148
00:07:34.910 --> 00:07:38.450
So you can't just throw metrics out if
you're gonna have to satisfy them, right?

149
00:07:38.450 --> 00:07:39.580
Of course cost focus.

150
00:07:39.580 --> 00:07:44.830
You can also measure what it
costs to reduce unavailability.

151
00:07:44.830 --> 00:07:46.890
I've been involved in those exercises.

152
00:07:46.890 --> 00:07:48.410
What does an outage cost us?

153
00:07:50.270 --> 00:07:52.616
I can look at what it costs IT, right?

154
00:07:52.616 --> 00:07:56.540
W e brought three technicians
in from 3 o'clock in the morning

155
00:07:56.540 --> 00:07:59.590
to 10 o'clock in the morning,
and they were working on things.

156
00:07:59.590 --> 00:08:03.810
They should have been working on other
things besides this service going down.

157
00:08:03.810 --> 00:08:05.360
So we lost that productivity.

158
00:08:05.360 --> 00:08:07.530
What does that protivity cost us?

159
00:08:07.530 --> 00:08:09.970
Add up the salaries,
come up with a dollar amount.

160
00:08:09.970 --> 00:08:10.710
That sort of thing.

161
00:08:10.710 --> 00:08:12.590
So there's ways to approach this.

162
00:08:12.590 --> 00:08:15.400
And remember there's also
cost to the business, right?

163
00:08:15.400 --> 00:08:17.970
What did it cost the business
because you were out?

164
00:08:17.970 --> 00:08:20.300
If you come out with
those kind of metrics,

165
00:08:20.300 --> 00:08:22.810
the business is gonna see
you as concerned about them.

166
00:08:22.810 --> 00:08:26.900
And not just you, they're concerned
about them and not just the DSLA, right?

167
00:08:26.900 --> 00:08:31.448
And if you're an external provider, of
course, you're gonna make your money back

168
00:08:31.448 --> 00:08:36.189
satisfying your contractual arrangements,
but you're gonna gain loyalty and retain

169
00:08:36.189 --> 00:08:40.695
customers if you can show that you're
actually focused on their outcomes, okay?

170
00:08:40.695 --> 00:08:44.220
So what are some challenges and risks
related to the availability management?

171
00:08:45.400 --> 00:08:49.470
Again, we kinda discuss
this as we go through.

172
00:08:49.470 --> 00:08:51.430
Another way to ask these questions,

173
00:08:51.430 --> 00:08:56.210

174
00:08:56.210 --> 00:08:59.580
You wanna be able to meet
the customer's expectations, right?

175
00:08:59.580 --> 00:09:02.682
Especially, again they're not
necessarily expecting 100% uptime,

176
00:09:02.682 --> 00:09:07.030
not necessarily, but they do want
you to be quick to recover, right?

177
00:09:07.030 --> 00:09:11.350
How can you integrate this data,
make it meaningful to people, right?

178
00:09:11.350 --> 00:09:13.890
So that you come up with proactive
measures more effectively and

179
00:09:13.890 --> 00:09:16.330
cost effectively, more efficiently, right?

180
00:09:17.350 --> 00:09:20.650
And convincing management that
you need to do this proactively.

181
00:09:21.900 --> 00:09:25.573
This is a great place to come,
test takers.

182
00:09:25.573 --> 00:09:30.367
If you come or pause on this particular
slide, if you look at challenges and

183
00:09:30.367 --> 00:09:35.390
risks you're going to get an idea of how
a test maker may form their questions,

184
00:09:35.390 --> 00:09:39.955
because they often go here to say,
I want to build a scenario around this

185
00:09:39.955 --> 00:09:43.714
kind of challenge to see if
they know how to fix it, right?

186
00:09:43.714 --> 00:09:44.810
That kind of thing.

187
00:09:44.810 --> 00:09:48.920
So as an example, you may be tasked,
as in this first example here where you

188
00:09:48.920 --> 00:09:53.440
have convincing management of the need for
proactive investment, right?

189
00:09:53.440 --> 00:09:57.690
You may be tasked through a scenario and
through a question.

190
00:09:58.710 --> 00:10:02.609
You have been asked to come to
a meeting of the CIO and the CEO,

191
00:10:02.609 --> 00:10:05.822

invest in availability

192
00:10:05.822 --> 00:10:09.971
management as a formal process and
have proactive investment.

193
00:10:09.971 --> 00:10:13.800
So what kind of data are you gonna

Upon the match and

35
00:01:31.180 --> 00:01:33.000

36
00:01:33.000 --> 00:01:35.320
Be the process,

37

00:01:56.454 --> 00:01:59.580

44
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:03.230

45
00:02:03.230 --> 00:02:07.270

46
00:02:07.270 --> 00:02:10.130

48
00:02:14.340 --> 00:02:18.190

49
00:02:18.190 --> 00:02:20.730

50
00:02:20.730 --> 00:02:22.840

52
00:02:26.500 --> 00:02:28.730
When we speak of that continuity,
we're thinking,

53
00:02:28.730 --> 00:02:32.090

actually performing business?

54
00:02:32.090 --> 00:02:34.180
>> Absolutely.
>> Versus availability, where yeah,

55
00:02:34.180 --> 00:02:36.740

56
00:02:36.740 --> 00:02:37.260
>> Right.
>> Gotcha.

57
00:02:37.260 --> 00:02:38.500
>> Exactly right.

58
00:02:38.500 --> 00:02:39.950
Absolutely, great example.

59
00:02:39.950 --> 00:02:41.820
You're really talking
about business impact and

60
00:02:41.820 --> 00:02:43.270
what is the business
continuity gonna be like.

61
00:02:43.270 --> 00:02:45.870
So this link up to business
continuity planning,

62
00:02:45.870 --> 00:02:48.990
is a key component of IT
service continuity planning.

63
00:02:48.990 --> 00:02:51.670
Putting them together,
not working in isolation.

64
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:53.270
Very good point.

65
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:57.110
So as we consider this then,
what is the scope?

66
00:02:57.110 --> 00:02:58.300
That's what you've gotta describe.

67
00:02:58.300 --> 00:03:02.080
Does it include, one of the things
the continuity management process and

68
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:05.530

69
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:08.350
Are we worried about when email goes down?

70
00:03:08.350 --> 00:03:10.278
Are we worried about
when a servers goes down?

71
00:03:10.278 --> 00:03:13.265

72
00:03:13.265 --> 00:03:17.540

74
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:27.520
So understanding what is the scope,
is a necessary first step in understanding

75

purpose of continuity management.

76

77
00:03:36.020 --> 00:03:37.950
Coming up with a strategy and a plan.

78
00:03:37.950 --> 00:03:39.590
The testing of those plans.

79
00:03:39.590 --> 00:03:41.550
And ongoing operation of those plans.

80
00:03:41.550 --> 00:03:46.250

00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:48.160
And just kind of set it

84

85
00:03:59.470 --> 00:04:04.760

86

87
00:04:09.430 --> 00:04:13.402
So again, if you wanna map this to life
cycle, we've got strategy life cycle,

88
00:04:13.402 --> 00:04:16.902
we've got design life cycle,
we've got transition life cycle, and

89
00:04:16.902 --> 00:04:20.110
then there it is operation,
ongoing operation of it.

90
00:04:20.110 --> 00:04:24.530
So you can kind of break down the major
stages of IT service continuity management

91
00:04:24.530 --> 00:04:28.070

a life cycle type approach.

92
00:04:28.070 --> 00:04:32.490
And we'll be focusing on that
very approach very soon, okay?

93
00:04:32.490 --> 00:04:33.710

94
00:04:33.710 --> 00:04:38.140
I think its somewhat obvious but

Linking IT Service Continuity Management

00:04:42.780 --> 00:04:48.010
If you consider that perhaps

100
00:04:54.300 --> 00:04:59.232
The business may come up with a business
continuity process that says,

101
00:04:59.232 --> 00:05:03.833
we could recap 50% of the production
of that particular plant or

my company and myself.

We've mentioned Demand Management

24

Demand management happens in
an earlier life cycle stage,

25
00:01:05.853 --> 00:01:11.940
it comes before capacity
management Still blank.

26
00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:13.696
Still just totally fine?
>> No, no good on this one.

27

>> All right, well, demand management
that intends to be predictive, right?

28

gonna be, and once you understand,

management discipline, right?

33

34

35

Or they might find that this is gonna
be a lot bigger than we thought, right?

39
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:57.910
So they're trying to be predictive
with this whole nature of

40
00:01:57.910 --> 00:01:59.880
what capacity might we need later.

41

So they come up with a process
earlier in the life cycle stage

43

And that's what we're gonna look at.

44
00:02:05.320 --> 00:02:09.990
If you take a look at the slides here,
then you'll see that the scope of

45
00:02:09.990 --> 00:02:14.470

analyze patterns of business activity.

46
00:02:14.470 --> 00:02:18.820
Like PBA, we saw that a little

47
00:02:18.820 --> 00:02:24.190
Patterns of Business Activity,
this refers to when do people use it and

48
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:26.720
how intensely they use it across time,
right.

49
00:02:28.320 --> 00:02:31.059
Month end reporting, weekly analysis,

50
00:02:31.059 --> 00:02:35.310
year-end performance reports,
those types of things.

51
00:02:35.310 --> 00:02:38.520
Another acronym here,

52
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:42.130
So this is breaking down

53
00:02:42.130 --> 00:02:45.139
Maybe the executives use it heavily,

54
00:02:45.139 --> 00:02:50.142
maybe the manufacturing team
uses it lightly, or vice versa.

55
00:02:50.142 --> 00:02:53.960
So understanding,
which type of users are doing what,

56
00:02:53.960 --> 00:02:57.250
is kind of a sub set of
patterns of business activity.

57
00:02:57.250 --> 00:03:00.815
So you got,
the super set of what the business does,

58
00:03:00.815 --> 00:03:03.011
the cycle of their activities.

59
00:03:03.011 --> 00:03:05.124
And then you get down into the weeds and

60
00:03:05.124 --> 00:03:08.452
find out what people do to take
in different types, right.

61
00:03:08.452 --> 00:03:13.090
So, demand management is going
to then drive the overall

62
00:03:13.090 --> 00:03:17.530
understanding of what we can
anticipate in demand of a service.

63
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:23.790
And of course, that informs capacity
management process quite a lot, okay?

64
00:03:23.790 --> 00:03:24.920
So you see these again.

65
00:03:24.920 --> 00:03:28.970
Identify and analyse, and
influence customer demand.

66

I cited an example on the capacity

67
00:03:33.578 --> 00:03:36.691

68

Which happened to be a day that

00:03:40.784 --> 00:03:42.580
a particular service.

70
00:03:42.580 --> 00:03:45.860
And, every other Friday,
with both of those things happening,

71
00:03:45.860 --> 00:03:48.380
our system suffered,
performance went way down.

72
00:03:48.380 --> 00:03:51.503
And, it took us awhile to figure that out,
honestly, we didn't just discover that.

73
00:03:51.503 --> 00:03:54.395
But, demand management would
try to predict that and

74
00:03:54.395 --> 00:03:58.660
actually ask enough questions,
interrogate the business enough.

75
00:03:58.660 --> 00:04:03.830
That they would understand that there's
gonna be a potential every other Friday,

76
00:04:03.830 --> 00:04:06.330
there's gonna be very heavy hitting.

77
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:08.200
And therefore, influence customer demand.

78
00:04:08.200 --> 00:04:09.132
In other words,

79
00:04:09.132 --> 00:04:13.300
ask the customer maybe to change
their behaviors a little bit, right?

80
00:04:13.300 --> 00:04:17.834
You can also influence customers'
demands through charging more, right?

81
00:04:17.834 --> 00:04:22.640
Is a classic example for internet service
providers, to charge you a premium for

82
00:04:22.640 --> 00:04:23.570
more.

83
00:04:23.570 --> 00:04:27.520
They're a way of kinda influencing
your demand, in many ways.

84
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:30.080
If you're concern about how slow it is,

85
00:04:30.080 --> 00:04:33.150
when everyone in your family is watching
a different movie in a different room.

86
00:04:33.150 --> 00:04:38.000
Because if you're Internet bandwidth,
speeds, then you might call them up and

87
00:04:38.000 --> 00:04:38.770
say, I need some more.

88
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:41.070
And say, well we got some more for
you, right?

89
00:04:41.070 --> 00:04:44.309
And a way to influence demand there,
is to make customers pay for it.

90
00:04:44.309 --> 00:04:47.269
Another example of influencing demand,

91
00:04:47.269 --> 00:04:51.420
is that we had a lot of people
asking a particular service.

92
00:04:51.420 --> 00:04:54.490
I mentioned this one earlier too, for

93
00:04:54.490 --> 00:04:58.060
converting PowerPoint
presentations to eLearning.

94
00:04:59.350 --> 00:05:01.690
At first, we just kind of opened
the flood gates, and says, yeah, yeah,

95
00:05:01.690 --> 00:05:03.300
we'll do that for you,
just send us what you got.

96
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:05.640
And they sent us everything, right?

97
00:05:05.640 --> 00:05:07.369
They didn't do any triage, whatsoever.

98
00:05:07.369 --> 00:05:11.473
So then we kind of influenced their demand
a little bit by saying, you know what,

99
00:05:11.473 --> 00:05:14.560
we're gonna start charging
a hundred dollars per conversion.

100
00:05:14.560 --> 00:05:16.770
And then, the business said,
okay, well, let me look,

101
00:05:16.770 --> 00:05:17.720
I'm not gonna send you 500, right?

102
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:20.130
>> All of a sudden, yeah, things get
a little more nuanced [INAUDIBLE]

103
00:05:20.130 --> 00:05:20.816
>> Yeah, yeah ,exactly.

104
00:05:20.816 --> 00:05:22.360
>> Maybe that's not as
important as hoped it was

105
00:05:22.360 --> 00:05:23.090
>> Yeah, exactly.

106
00:05:23.090 --> 00:05:24.240
We never supposed to have that.

107
00:05:24.240 --> 00:05:25.035
So they had some skin in the game.

108
00:05:25.035 --> 00:05:26.376
Some financial skin in the game so,

109
00:05:26.376 --> 00:05:28.355
when that was away we kind
of influenced demand too.

110
00:05:28.355 --> 00:05:32.960
So, this demand management thing can
be nuanced in that way as well, okay?

111
00:05:34.610 --> 00:05:37.225
As we look, the business value is
you're trying to predict, right?

112
00:05:37.225 --> 00:05:41.719
So you're trying to achieve a balance
between what you're going to build and

113
00:05:41.719 --> 00:05:43.970
what you're gonna deliver, right?

114
00:05:43.970 --> 00:05:46.670
Making sure you have
the right balance there.

115
00:05:46.670 --> 00:05:50.630
Asking these questions earlier,
ITIL suggest, gives you a better sense for

116
00:05:50.630 --> 00:05:54.050
how you can effectively plan for
capacity later on, right.

117
00:05:54.050 --> 00:05:57.331
And again, it also gives you
the ability to influence demand, okay?

118
00:05:59.269 --> 00:06:06.886
Underserved, I sometimes read this
as undeserved, but it's underserved.

119
00:06:06.886 --> 00:06:11.290
Underserved demand is a source of risk,
right?

120
00:06:11.290 --> 00:06:15.610
That means you have a lot more
demands you're able to satisfy, right?

121
00:06:15.610 --> 00:06:18.105
You don't have enough resources,
you don't have enough servers,

122
00:06:18.105 --> 00:06:20.829
you don't have enough people,
you don't have enough headsets, right?

123
00:06:20.829 --> 00:06:23.841
You don't have enough phones,
whatever it might be,

124
00:06:23.841 --> 00:06:27.650
underserved demand as a source of risk,
not having that available.

125
00:06:27.650 --> 00:06:33.290
So, excess capacity on the other hand
generates costs with no value, right?

126
00:06:33.290 --> 00:06:34.250
You over built it.

127
00:06:34.250 --> 00:06:41.180
You got, 120,000 headsets on a shelf and
no one's using.

128
00:06:41.180 --> 00:06:41.982
That's sort of thing, right?

129
00:06:41.982 --> 00:06:45.130
So excess capacity, generates cost.

130
00:06:45.130 --> 00:06:49.150
So trying to find that balance is what
demand management is trying to figure out.

131
00:06:49.150 --> 00:06:53.080
>> It's like buying a helicopter
to fly a hundred yards.

132
00:06:53.080 --> 00:06:53.890
>> Exactly, yeah.

133
00:06:53.890 --> 00:06:55.792
>> It's completely more than unique.

134
00:06:55.792 --> 00:06:58.550
>> Way over kill,
good example, way over kill.

135
00:06:58.550 --> 00:07:01.550
So you're only trying to get
this nice little balance here.

136
00:07:01.550 --> 00:07:04.340
As you can see on this
graphic in particular,

00:07:04.340 --> 00:07:06.590

138
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:11.290
But as price goes up, right, quantity,
getting the right supply mix,

139
00:07:11.290 --> 00:07:13.850

that nice little sweet spot.

140
00:07:13.850 --> 00:07:17.560
So you're not providing too much,
you are not spending too much.

141
00:07:17.560 --> 00:07:19.420
It's really all it amounts to.

142
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:25.721
This is just a graphical representation

143
00:07:25.721 --> 00:07:28.832
Now, this is a very interesting
graphic in lot a ways.

144
00:07:28.832 --> 00:07:29.942
This seems like,

145
00:07:29.942 --> 00:07:34.905

like a snake swallowing it's on tail.

146
00:07:34.905 --> 00:07:38.809
It's bit more nuance than that.

147
00:07:38.809 --> 00:07:44.290
As usage increases, demand increases.

148
00:07:44.290 --> 00:07:47.270
Again, doesn't that sound just
like a self fulfilling prophecy?

149
00:07:47.270 --> 00:07:48.390
But let me add some nuance.

150
00:07:48.390 --> 00:07:50.040
It's actually more of an engine.

151
00:07:50.040 --> 00:07:54.820
In other words, as it's used,
it's going to be used more.

152
00:07:54.820 --> 00:07:56.810
That's really what I'm trying to get at.

153
00:07:56.810 --> 00:07:57.799
>> It's a perpetual motion engine.

154
00:07:57.799 --> 00:07:59.860
>> Almost, it's just spinning.

155
00:07:59.860 --> 00:08:01.544
It's almost like an engine.

156
00:08:01.544 --> 00:08:03.559
So I'll give you a couple examples.

157
00:08:03.559 --> 00:08:12.902
And it's been proven.

158
00:08:12.902 --> 00:08:19.030
As I used that service amazon.com,
I thought, that service is good.

159
00:08:19.030 --> 00:08:20.800
I said, you know what,
I can go to Amazon.com.

160
00:08:20.800 --> 00:08:22.120
I can do that, right?

161
00:08:22.120 --> 00:08:24.130
I tell my friends about it, right?

162
00:08:24.130 --> 00:08:24.930
Yeah, I can do that.

163
00:08:24.930 --> 00:08:32.860
So as I used it I found more use for
it so I came back to it again, right?

164
00:08:32.860 --> 00:08:38.450
That's the nature of this kind of
engine is that in the dynamic of usage,

165
00:08:38.450 --> 00:08:40.240
demand can increase.

166
00:08:40.240 --> 00:08:43.470
So, it's not quite like a snake
swallowing its own tail,

167
00:08:43.470 --> 00:08:47.620
it's more like Daniel said like
a propelled engine, right.

168
00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.140
Not self propelled-
>> Perpetual motion.

169
00:08:51.140 --> 00:08:51.810
>> Perpetual motion.

170
00:08:51.810 --> 00:08:53.077
>> There you go.
>> Thanks for the clarification.

171
00:08:53.077 --> 00:08:53.852
>> Yeah.

172
00:08:53.852 --> 00:08:57.700
>> But at any rate it is,
it kinda just exponentially grows.

173
00:08:57.700 --> 00:09:01.183
So demand management is
trying to anticipate that,

174
00:09:01.183 --> 00:09:03.010
what might this look like?

175
00:09:03.010 --> 00:09:06.160
Maybe one a little bit closer to my own
experience was again in this learning

176
00:09:06.160 --> 00:09:07.060
management system.

177
00:09:07.060 --> 00:09:11.566
As people use the learning management
service in the system they began to find

178
00:09:11.566 --> 00:09:14.980
more value in that and
came back to it more often.

179
00:09:14.980 --> 00:09:17.360
Right, so it started off kinda slow.

180
00:09:17.360 --> 00:09:19.190
No one just rushed to it, but

181
00:09:19.190 --> 00:09:23.690
as they begin to use it they had more
reasons to come back to it, right?

182
00:09:23.690 --> 00:09:25.780
That's what I'm talking about, okay.

183
00:09:26.930 --> 00:09:29.600
So, again, we'll see this little
graphic here quite often.

184
00:09:29.600 --> 00:09:31.820
The matching of demand and
capacity requires study.

185
00:09:31.820 --> 00:09:33.080
What are they up to?

186
00:09:33.080 --> 00:09:37.320
Looking at the customers, patterns of
business activity, asking them questions.

187
00:09:37.320 --> 00:09:39.682
Now, that could be very challenging.

188
00:09:39.682 --> 00:09:43.882
The same example I mentioned earlier where
the manufacturing group was doing their

189
00:09:43.882 --> 00:09:45.084
queries every Friday.

190
00:09:45.084 --> 00:09:49.056
And the sales teams were
coming every other Friday and

191
00:09:49.056 --> 00:09:52.239
heavily hitting the system for training.

192
00:09:52.239 --> 00:09:56.620
Even if we had a mature demand management
process, and I'll admit that we didn't.

193
00:09:56.620 --> 00:10:01.468
But even if we did probably getting
that kind of intelligence early,

194
00:10:01.468 --> 00:10:04.234
would have probably been really hard.

195
00:10:04.234 --> 00:10:07.364
Asking the right kind of questions
to the right number of people.

196
00:10:07.364 --> 00:10:11.684
We might not ever have gotten those data
points to put the two together to say.

197
00:10:11.684 --> 00:10:14.512
Hm these things all happen on Friday,
right?

198
00:10:14.512 --> 00:10:16.703
So I appreciate the challenge of this.

199
00:10:16.703 --> 00:10:19.065
It's not necessarily a walk in the park,
but

200
00:10:19.065 --> 00:10:23.060
demand management as Itel would put it,
on the perfect little Itel island.

201
00:10:23.060 --> 00:10:28.558
Would be a very good way to predict
these demand constraints and

202
00:10:28.558 --> 00:10:34.484
discern their patterns of business
activity ahead of time, okay.

203
00:10:34.484 --> 00:10:39.100
So, it all comes around to gearing,
how you wanna get this engine just right.

204
00:10:39.100 --> 00:10:44.490
So gearing your service assets, remember
assets are resources and capabilities.

205
00:10:44.490 --> 00:10:47.672
So it's people, it's servers,
it's the number of headsets
